Case Name: Amarendra Komalam Vs. Usha Sinha
Issue Presented: Can the renewal clause interpolation issue be re-litigated after having been expressly waived in a prior case and upheld by the Supreme Court?
Facts of the Case: The dispute concerns the renewal clause of a lease agreement executed on 02.09.1978.
Ruling by Lower Court: he Lower Court and High Court ruled in favor of the respondent, despite the prior Supreme Court decision.
Argument: Petitioner argues that the issue is barred by res judicata, waiver, estoppel and the clause was altered fraudulently and should be examined.
Statute: Res Judicata Doctrine under CPC to Prevents re-litigation of the same matter.
Rules: Prior acceptance of a legal position prevents reassertion.Order 7, Rule 11 of CPC.
Precedent: Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in S.L.P.(C) No. 16513 of 2001.
Ratio of the Decision: Principle of Finality – Once waived, an issue cannot be revived in subsequent cases.
Ruling: High Court ruling contradicts established legal precedent.

Case Name: Karnataka Rare Earth Vs. The Senior Geologist, Department of Mines and Geology and Anr
Respondent: Senior Geologist, Department of Mines and Geology and Another
Issue Presented: Does the demand for the price of mineral raised and exported amount to a penalt.
Facts of the Case: The court held that the demand for mineral price was compensatory, not a penalty, as marginal notes do not control statutory meaning.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the appeals, affirming that the recovery was compensatory and not penal.
Argument: Petitioner claims arbitrary rejection and lack of due process.
Rules: Rule 24A of Mineral Concession Rules, 1960.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court ruling on discretionary powers in mining leases.
Ratio of the Decision: Environmental concerns outweigh commercial interests.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the government decision.

Case Name: Rajesh Kumar and Ors Vs. Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Respondent: Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Issue Presented: Validity of a special audit order under Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act was procedurally and legally justified.
Facts of the Case: The appellants’ premises were raided in 2002, with financial records being seized. A notice for undisclosed income was issued, followed by a special audit order.The audit was based on discrepancies in accounting records.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tribunal upheld the special audit order.
Argument: Petitioner argued that there was no justification for the special audit and it was arbitrary.
Rules: Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on the necessity of reasoned orders in tax matters.
Ratio of the Decision: A special audit must be based on substantive discrepancies and procedural adherence.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, setting aside the special audit order.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Surjit Singh
Issue Presented: Whether daily wage workers are entitled to equal pay under the "Equal Pay for Equal Work" principle.
Facts of the Case: Respondents worked as daily wagers in Punjab's Public Health Department. No proper recruitment process was followed. The High Court ruled in favor of the respondents, granting them the minimum pay scale with dearness allowance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the respondents based on prior case law.
Argument: Opposed equal pay for daily wagers, citing procedural deficiencies in hiring. Advocated for pay parity based on continuous service.
Statute: Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: Service Rules of Punjab Government of "Equal Pay for Equal Work".
Precedent: Ranbir Singh vs. State of Haryana (1998).
Ratio of the Decision: Continuous employment justifies minimum pay parity, even for daily wage workers.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the entitlement to minimum pay scale with dearness allowance but set aside parts of the High Court ruling.

Case Name: Bengal Enamel Works Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether remuneration paid to Dr. Ganguly should be fully deductible under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.
Facts of the Case: The company was engaged in enamelware manufacturing.The company claimed full remuneration as a deductible business expense.The Tribunal upheld the disallowance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal confirmed the partial disallowance.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the remuneration was justified based on expertise and contribution maintained that the excess amount was not exclusively for business purposes.
Rules: Business expenses must be necessary and exclusively incurred for business. Section 40A(2) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on reasonable expenses under tax laws.
Ratio of the Decision: A portion of the remuneration was deemed excessive and not justified as a necessary business expense.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the disallowance, agreeing that the limit set by the Tribunal was justified.

Case Name: Delhi Development Authority Vs. Skipper Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the construction company engaged in fraudulent activities and misled buyers.
Facts of the Case: Skipper Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd. misrepresented ownership of properties and sold units without approval, causing financial harm to consumers.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court found the company guilty of fraudulent practices and directed refunds to affected consumers.
Argument: The petitioner contended that fraudulent misrepresentation and lack of legal authorization made the transactions invalid.
Statute: Consumer Protection Act, 1986; Indian Contract Act, 1872.
Rules: The court examined real estate laws and previous rulings on fraudulent transactions.
Precedent: The decision followed Supreme Court precedents on consumer fraud and real estate misrepresentation.
Ratio of the Decision: Fraudulent practices by real estate developers are punishable under consumer protection laws, ensuring accountability.
Ruling: The Supreme Court directed refunds and penalties, reinforcing the importance of consumer rights in real estate transactions.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. R. Gandhi
Issue Presented: Whether the establishment of NCLT and NCLAT violated the constitutional separation of powers.
Facts of the Case: The establishment of company law tribunals was challenged on the grounds that they encroached upon the judiciary’s domain.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that while the tribunals were constitutionally valid, certain procedural changes were needed to maintain independence.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the tribunals were established as per constitutional provisions.
Statute: Companies Act, 1956; Indian Constitution (provisions related to judicial independence).
Rules: The court evaluated rules governing tribunal appointments and functions.
Precedent: Past judgments on judicial independence and tribunal structure were considered.
Ratio of the Decision: Tribunals must function autonomously while adhering to constitutional principles.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that NCLT and NCLAT were valid but directed changes in appointment procedures to preserve judicial independence.

Case Name: Lalita Kumari Vs. Government of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Obligation of police to register an FIR in cognizable offenses.
Facts of the Case: Lalita Kumari filed a writ petition after police failed to register an FIR in a reported kidnapping case.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that non-registration of FIRs in cognizable cases was a violation of legal duty.
Argument: The petitioner contended that police refusal to register an FIR violated legal provisions and fundamental rights.
Rules: Section 154 of CrPC, which outlines the duty of police officers in cognizable cases.
Precedent: Previous cases related to FIR registration and police discretion in investigating offenses.
Ratio of the Decision: Police officers must register FIRs for cognizable offenses, but limited discretion is allowed in certain cases.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that police must register FIRs in cognizable offenses but permitted a preliminary inquiry in select cases.

Case Name: Shreya Singhal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of Section 66A of the IT Act in relation to free speech.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged Section 66A after individuals were arrested for online speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that Section 66A was essential for controlling online abuse and maintaining order.
Argument: The High Court ruled that Section 66A was essential for controlling online abuse and maintaining order.
Rules: Section 66A of the IT Act, which penalized online speech deemed "offensive" or "annoying".
Precedent: Supreme Court judgments on freedom of speech and judicial review of vague laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Laws that lack clarity and enable arbitrary arrests violate the principles of free speech and due process.
Ruling: The Supreme Court invalidated Section 66A, ruling that it violated free speech and was excessively vague.

Case Name: Vishaka & Ors Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Lack of legal framework for workplace sexual harassment and the need for judicial intervention.
Facts of the Case: The case arose from a brutal assault on a woman at her workplace, highlighting the absence of legal protections against sexual harassment in India.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that in the absence of legislation, it could not grant relief.
Argument: The High Court ruled that in the absence of legislation, it could not grant relief.
Statute: The High Court ruled that in the absence of legislation, it could not grant relief.
Rules: International conventions such as CEDAW, which India had ratified, were used to justify judicial intervention.
Precedent: The case set a precedent in recognizing workplace harassment as a violation of fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Protection against sexual harassment is a constitutional obligation, and guidelines are necessary until a law is enacted.
Ruling: The Supreme Court issued the Vishaka Guidelines, making them binding until Parliament enacted specific legislation.

Case Name: Aruna Shanbaug Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legality of withdrawing life support for patients in a permanent vegetative state.
Facts of the Case: A nurse remained in a vegetative state for over three decades due to a violent attack, and a petition was filed to allow withdrawal of life support.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against allowing euthanasia due to the absence of a legal framework.
Argument: Prolonged suffering without hope of recovery is inhumane and violates Article 21 of the Constitution.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 21; International laws on euthanasia.
Rules: The Court examined international laws and medical ethics regarding end-of-life care.
Precedent: No existing legal precedent in India on euthanasia before this case.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to life includes the right to die with dignity in extreme medical conditions, but euthanasia must be strictly regulated.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that passive euthanasia is permissible under regulated conditions but emphasized the need for strict procedural safeguards.

Case Name: Navtej Singh Johar Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 377 IPC violates fundamental rights of LGBTQ+ individuals.
Facts of the Case: A petition was filed against Section 377, arguing that it criminalized consensual same-sex relations and violated human dignity and privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of LGBTQ+ rights and struck down Section 377.
Argument: Criminalization of same-sex relations violates the rights to equality, privacy, and freedom of expression.
Statute: Indian Penal Code, Section 377; Constitution of India - Fundamental Rights.
Rules: Supreme Court examined the right to privacy and individual autonomy in light of past rulings.
Precedent: Previous rulings on privacy and individual rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Section 377 was unconstitutional to the extent that it criminalized consensual adult relationships.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that Section 377 is unconstitutional when applied to consenting adults.

Case Name: Maneka Gandhi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the government’s action violated the principles of natural justice and personal liberty.
Facts of the Case: Maneka Gandhi’s passport was seized by the government under the Passports Act, without giving her an opportunity to be heard, raising concerns over due process.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the government, stating it had authority under the law.
Argument: She argued that personal liberty includes the right to travel, and restrictions must be just, fair, and reasonable.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 21; Passports Act, 1967.
Rules: The judiciary examined the expansion of Article 21 to include due process and procedural fairness.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on personal liberty and fundamental rights were considered.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to life and personal liberty must include procedural safeguards against arbitrary actions by the state.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that personal liberty cannot be curtailed arbitrarily.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Corporate accountability for environmental damage caused by industrial activities.
Facts of the Case: A hazardous gas leak caused severe harm, leading to legal scrutiny of industrial responsibility for pollution.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held the company liable and imposed penalties.
Argument: Emphasized corporate accountability, demanding preventive measures and stringent environmental safeguards.
Rules: Established stricter liability principles for industries causing pollution.
Precedent: Considered previous cases on environmental liability, shaping future laws on industrial disasters.
Ratio of the Decision: Absolute liability principle ensures that industrial enterprises causing pollution must compensate victims without exceptions.
Ruling: Supreme Court established absolute liability, making companies responsible for any industrial disasters.

Case Name: Olga Tellis Vs. Bombay Municipal Corporation
Issue Presented: Right to shelter and livelihood as part of fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The Bombay Municipal Corporation issued demolition and eviction notices to slum dwellers, leading to concerns over fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the municipal action, arguing it was in line with urban planning regulations.
Argument: Contended that evictions without rehabilitation measures denied slum dwellers their right to life and dignity.
Rules: The right to livelihood and shelter as an extension of Article 21.
Precedent: Considered prior cases on forced evictions, emphasizing human dignity and socio-economic rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Livelihood and shelter are fundamental rights, and evictions must be accompanied.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that slum dwellers have a right to livelihood.

Case Name: Indra Sawhney Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of OBC reservations and defining limits for affirmative action.
Facts of the Case: The government implemented Mandal Commission recommendations, leading to protests and legal challenges over fairness and proportionality.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of reservations, dismissing challenges on constitutional grounds.
Argument: Opposed reservations exceeding 50%, contending that they infringe upon equal opportunity.
Statute: Articles 14, 15, 16 (Equality, Non-discrimination, Reservations in Public Employment).
Rules: Social justice principles and constitutional limits on reservations.
Precedent: Earlier decisions on reservations and merit-based selection.
Ratio of the Decision: OBC reservations are legal, but economically advanced groups within OBCs must be excluded.
Ruling: Affirmed OBC reservations but introduced the creamy layer test, restricting benefits to the most disadvantaged.

Case Name: Minerva Mills Ltd. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Validity of constitutional amendments in relation to the basic structure doctrine.
Facts of the Case: The 42nd Amendment increased the power of Directive Principles, raising concerns over fundamental rights being weakened.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court supported the constitutional changes, rejecting concerns over Fundamental Rights.
Argument: Contended that expanding Directive Principles at the cost of Fundamental Rights distorts constitutional balance.
Rules: Constitutional amendment powers and limitations under Article 368.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the scope of constitutional amendments.
Ratio of the Decision: Amendments must respect the basic structure doctrine, and Fundamental Rights remain supreme.
Ruling: Supreme Court invalidated portions of the amendment, ensuring that Fundamental Rights remain protected.

Case Name: ADM Jabalpur Vs. Shivkant Shukla
Issue Presented: Validity of detentions without trial under Emergency provisions.
Facts of the Case: The government detained individuals without providing legal remedies, citing Emergency powers.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court declared detentions unconstitutional, reinforcing individual liberty.
Argument: Contended that state security takes precedence over individual liberty in times of Emergency.
Rules: Doctrine of necessity vs. fundamental rights under constitutional law.
Precedent: Judicial review of Emergency provisions in past cases.
Ratio of the Decision: National security interests can temporarily supersede fundamental rights under Emergency provisions.
Ruling: Supreme Court sided with the state, affirming the broad powers granted during an Emergency.

Case Name: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether fundamental rights can be altered through constitutional amendments.
Facts of the Case: A religious institution challenged land reform laws, arguing that Parliament’s power to amend the Constitution was not unlimited.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the government, validating the amendments.
Argument: Asserted that there must be limits on Parliament’s amending power, and fundamental rights should not be diluted.
Rules: Judicial review of constitutional amendments, assessing whether amendments can modify fundamental rights.
Precedent: This case established a landmark precedent on constitutional amendments.
Ratio of the Decision: The amending power under Article 368 is subject to inherent limitations, preventing fundamental distortions.
Ruling: The amending power under Article 368 is subject to inherent limitations, preventing fundamental distortions.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Taj Trapezium Case)
Issue Presented: Whether polluting industries should be relocated to prevent damage to the Taj Mahal.
Facts of the Case: Polluting industries around the Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ) were degrading the monument’s marble structure.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court directed the government to regulate industrial activity near the Taj Mahal.
Argument: Relocation of hazardous industries is necessary to prevent irreversible damage to the Taj Mahal.
Statute: Environmental Protection Act, 1986, Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974.
Rules: Heritage conservation laws and environmental impact assessments guide industrial regulation.
Precedent: Earlier rulings on industrial pollution and environmental safeguards.
Ratio of the Decision: Polluting industries must be relocated if they pose an environmental risk to heritage sites.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated stricter environmental regulations and relocation of hazardous industries.

Case Name: DK Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Rights of arrested persons and safeguards against custodial abuse.
Facts of the Case: Increasing cases of police brutality and custodial deaths raised concerns over human rights violations.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court suggested procedural reforms but left enforcement to the discretion of authorities.
Argument: Argued that the state must ensure the safety and dignity of arrested persons, as per Article 21.
Statute: Article 21, Criminal Procedure Code provisions on arrest and detention.
Rules: Legal safeguards against arbitrary detention and police abuse.
Precedent: Previous judgments on police accountability and human rights violations.
Ratio of the Decision: Arrested individuals are entitled to dignity and protection from abuse.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated procedural safeguards, including medical examinations and legal representation for detainees.

Case Name: Lily Thomas Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Validity of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Facts of the Case: The provision enabled sitting MPs and MLAs to avoid immediate disqualification despite criminal convictions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the provision, maintaining the status quo.
Argument: Contended that the provision enabled corruption and eroded public trust in governance.
Rules: Legal interpretation of disqualification and its impact on governance.
Precedent: Judicial rulings on political accountability and public trust.
Ratio of the Decision: Immediate disqualification strengthens democracy by ensuring accountability.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that convicted MPs and MLAs lose their seats immediately upon conviction.

Case Name: People Union for Civil Liberties Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legality of phone tapping and its impact on fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The government was tapping phone conversations without adequate safeguards, leading to concerns over privacy violations.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that phone tapping was permissible under certain conditions but required oversight.
Argument: Contended that phone tapping without judicial oversight leads to misuse and human rights violations.
Rules: Surveillance laws must adhere to constitutional safeguards.
Precedent: Judicial rulings on privacy and state surveillance.
Ratio of the Decision: Government surveillance must be subject to checks and balances to prevent abuse.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated that phone tapping must follow strict legal procedures and oversight.

Case Name: S. R. Bommai Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutional validity of dismissing state governments under Article 356.
Facts of the Case: The President dismissed several state governments using Article 356, raising concerns over federalism and democracy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court supported the central government’s authority in imposing President’s rule.
Argument: Claimed that the dismissal violated the principles of federalism and democracy.
Rules: Judicial review of executive power and federal structure principles.
Precedent: Past judgments on President’s rule and constitutional breakdowns.
Ratio of the Decision: Federalism must be maintained, and President’s rule cannot be used to suppress opposition governments.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that judicial review is necessary to prevent misuse and protect state autonomy.

Case Name: Mohd. Ahmed Khan Vs. Shah Bano Begum
Issue Presented: Whether Section 125 CrPC overrides Muslim personal law in maintenance matters.
Facts of the Case: Shah Bano, after being divorced, claimed maintenance under Section 125 CrPC, arguing it applies to all women.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court upheld Shah Bano’s claim, granting maintenance.
Argument: The petitioner argued that maintenance obligations end after the iddat period under Islamic law.
Rules: Section 125 CrPC, which ensures financial support irrespective of religious laws.
Precedent: The case established that maintenance laws under CrPC are secular and cannot be nullified by personal laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored that Section 125 aims to prevent destitution and applies universally, irrespective of religion.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s verdict, affirming that Muslim women are entitled to maintenance beyond the iddat period.

Case Name: I. R. Coelho Vs. State of Tamil Nadu
Issue Presented: Whether the judiciary has the authority to review laws protected under the Ninth Schedule.
Facts of the Case: Laws placed in the Ninth Schedule were claimed to be beyond judicial review, but concerns were raised about potential violations of fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: Lower courts affirmed that the Ninth Schedule provided immunity from judicial review.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that laws violating fundamental rights should still be subject to review.
Statute: Constitutional provisions regarding the Ninth Schedule and its implications.
Rules: Fundamental principles governing judicial review and constitutional amendments.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati and Minerva Mills cases on judicial review and constitutional protection.
Ratio of the Decision: The judiciary has the authority to review laws in the Ninth Schedule if they violate the Constitution’s Basic Structure.
Ruling: The ruling reaffirmed that laws violating fundamental rights cannot be completely shielded from judicial review.

Case Name: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Industrial waste contamination affecting local communities.
Facts of the Case: Industrial waste led to severe environmental damage.
Ruling by Lower Court: Lower court imposed penalties on polluting industries.
Argument: Negligence by industries must be addressed under strict liability.
Rules: Strict environmental liability and industrial sustainability.
Precedent: Landmark environmental cases enforcing industrial responsibility.
Ratio of the Decision: Polluting industries must mitigate damage and compensate victims.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld strict liability for industries.

Case Name: Naz Foundation Vs. Government of NCT of Delhi
Issue Presented: Challenge to the constitutionality of Section 377 IPC.
Facts of the Case: LGBTQ+ individuals faced criminalization and legal discrimination under Section 377.
Ruling by Lower Court: Delhi High Court ruled that Section 377 was unconstitutional as it violated Article 21.
Argument: Petitioner argued that criminalizing homosexuality violated the right to privacy, dignity, and equality.
Rules: Equality and non-discrimination principles.
Precedent: Cases upholding individual autonomy and human dignity.
Ratio of the Decision: Legal provisions must align with evolving human rights standards.
Ruling: Supreme Court reinstated Section 377 in 2013 but decriminalized it in 2018.

Case Name: Puttaswamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Aadhaar’s data collection violates the right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: The case was a challenge to the constitutional validity of Aadhaar, focusing on whether collecting biometric data infringed on individual privacy. The government argued that Aadhaar enabled efficient governance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the government, holding that Aadhaar was constitutionally valid.
Argument: The right to privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21. Aadhaar ensures better service delivery and does not violate fundamental rights.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 21 (Right to Life and Personal Liberty).
Rules: Right to privacy, digital identity laws, and state surveillance.
Precedent: Cases on state surveillance, personal freedom, and constitutional rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Privacy is a constitutionally guaranteed right, but reasonable restrictions apply.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that privacy is a fundamental right, but upheld Aadhaar with restrictions.

Case Name: Keshub Mahindra Vs. Union of India (Bhopal Gas Tragedy Case)
Issue Presented: Legal accountability of corporations in industrial disasters.
Facts of the Case: The Bhopal Gas Tragedy resulted in severe environmental and human damage. Legal proceedings focused on corporate responsibility and liability.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court held the company liable but provided reduced criminal penalties.
Argument: The disaster was accidental, and criminal liability should be minimal. Negligence in plant maintenance caused the leak.
Statute: Environmental laws, corporate liability statutes, and public safety regulations.
Rules: Corporate liability, industrial disaster compensation, and environmental regulations.
Precedent: Landmark cases on corporate negligence and mass torts.
Ratio of the Decision: Industrial corporations are strictly liable for hazardous operations.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld corporate responsibility, ensuring financial restitution and legal accountability.

Case Name: Golaknath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutional limits on Parliament’s power to amend fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: Golaknath family challenged the Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, claiming it violated their fundamental rights to property by preventing judicial review of land reform laws.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld Parliament’s authority to amend fundamental rights.
Argument: Fundamental rights are absolute and cannot be altered. Parliament has full amending power under Article 368.
Rules: Constitutional amendment rules, judicial review doctrine.
Precedent: No precedent restricting Parliament’s amending power before this case.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling restricted Parliament’s authority, marking a shift toward judicial supremacy over constitutional amendments.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that Parliament cannot amend fundamental rights, though this decision was later reversed in Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973), introducing the Basic Structure Doctrine.

Case Name: Union Carbide Corporation Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legality and adequacy of the compensation settlement for Bhopal Gas Tragedy victims.
Facts of the Case: The Bhopal Gas Tragedy caused thousands of deaths and severe injuries due to a toxic gas leak from Union Carbide’s plant. In 1989, UCC and the Indian government settled the case for $470 million, but victims’ groups challenged the amount as inadequate.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the settlement but allowed petitions from victims' families for additional relief.
Argument: The agreed settlement was legally binding and should not be reopened. The compensation was insufficient, and Union Carbide should provide more financial relief.
Statute: Bhopal Gas Leak Disaster (Processing of Claims) Act, 1985.
Rules: Absolute liability principle, industrial disaster compensation laws.
Precedent: Cases involving corporate liability for environmental disasters.
Ratio of the Decision: The settlement must be fair, just, and ensure full rehabilitation of the victims.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the $470 million settlement but permitted victims to file additional claims for further compensation.

Case Name: Sheela Barse Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Whether women prisoners in Maharashtra were being subjected to inhumane treatment and custodial abuse.
Facts of the Case: Journalist Sheela Barse filed a PIL after investigating custodial abuse of women prisoners in Maharashtra. The case raised concerns over violations of fundamental rights and the lack of legal protection mechanisms in prisons.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court implemented some reforms but did not introduce strict enforcement measures.
Argument: Women prisoners faced mistreatment, and urgent reforms were needed. Prison authorities argued that existing rules were sufficient.
Statute: Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, Right to Life and Dignity.
Rules: Human rights guidelines for prisoners and safeguards against custodial violence.
Precedent: D.K. Basu case on custodial violence and human rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Women prisoners must be protected from custodial violence, and stronger monitoring mechanisms are necessary.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ordered significant reforms in the treatment and legal safeguards for women prisoners.

Case Name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legal recognition and eradication of bonded labor under human rights law.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed, exposing the widespread use of bonded labor in industries, particularly in mines and brick kilns. The case questioned the government’s failure to enforce labor laws and protect vulnerable workers.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court acknowledged the problem but did not issue a comprehensive directive.
Argument: Bonded labor violates human dignity and constitutional rights. The government defended its existing labor policies.
Rules: Principles of labor rights, human dignity, and welfare laws.
Precedent: Prior judgments on forced labor and the enforcement of minimum wage laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The practice of bonded labor is unconstitutional, and the government must act to rehabilitate affected workers.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated strict enforcement of labor laws and directed rehabilitation measures for bonded laborers.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Krishna Kumar
Issue Presented: Legality of state reservation policies in education.
Facts of the Case: The State of Karnataka implemented an education policy that excluded a certain student category from reservations. The policy was challenged on constitutional grounds, asserting that denial of reservations violated fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the students, mandating that the state uphold reservation policies fairly.
Argument: The state argued that financial limitations and administrative challenges justified restricting reservations. The students, led by Krishna Kumar, argued that reservation is a constitutional guarantee under Article 21A and must be fairly executed.
Rules: Reservation laws in education policy.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservations.
Ratio of the Decision: Denying reservation access based on financial or administrative grounds is unconstitutional.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s ruling, stating that the state must ensure equitable access to education through reservations.

Case Name: Ramesh Dalal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether convicted MPs and MLAs should be immediately disqualified from holding office upon conviction.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner raised concerns that convicted legislators continued in office due to legal delays, which allowed them to influence the system and remain in power.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that MPs and MLAs could continue in office while appealing their conviction, citing provisions under the Representation of the People Act.
Argument: The petitioner argued that disqualifying convicted politicians immediately would prevent corruption and reinforce electoral integrity.
Rules: Provisions for disqualification of public officials upon criminal conviction.
Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on disqualification of convicted legislators, including the Lily Thomas case.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that maintaining convicted legislators in office contradicts democratic principles and erodes public trust.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that MPs and MLAs are disqualified immediately upon conviction, nullifying the previous practice of allowing them to serve until their appeal is decided.

Case Name: Mohini Jain Vs. State of Karnataka
Issue Presented: Whether the charging of capitation fees by private educational institutions violates the right to education.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the Karnataka government’s policy allowing private medical colleges to charge high capitation fees.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of private medical colleges, stating that they had the right to determine their own admission policies and fee structures.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that education should be based on merit and not financial status. She argued that denying admission due to an inability to pay capitation fees violates the right to education.
Rules: Provisions regulating private educational institutions and their admission processes.
Precedent: Unni Krishnan case, which further elaborated on the right to education.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that education is a fundamental right, and imposing capitation fees violates the principle of equal opportunity in access to education.
Ruling: The Supreme Court struck down the practice of capitation fees as unconstitutional, reinforcing education as a fundamental right under Article 21A.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Madhukar Narayan Mardikar
Issue Presented: Whether a woman’s right to privacy and protection under the law depends on her moral character.
Facts of the Case: The case involved the denial of legal protection to a woman based on her profession, leading to concerns about equal legal treatment.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the woman’s right to dignity and ruled that her profession should not affect her access to justice.
Argument: Petitioner argued that a woman’s moral standing could be a determining factor in her access to legal protection.
Rules: Gender equality and right to privacy under fundamental rights.
Precedent: Landmark cases reinforcing the right to privacy and dignity for all individuals.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to dignity and privacy applies universally and cannot be restricted by profession.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that all women are entitled to equal legal protection, regardless of profession.

Case Name: Jarnail Singh Vs. Lachhmi Narain Gupta
Issue Presented: Whether reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees require supporting quantifiable data.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contested the government's decision to grant reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees without proving backwardness through quantifiable data.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against automatic reservations in promotions and emphasized the need for empirical data to justify them.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the absence of empirical data on backwardness makes reservation in promotions unconstitutional.
Rules: The necessity of data-driven policies for reservations in promotions.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case, which established criteria for reservations, including the necessity of quantifiable data.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court reinforced that reservations in promotions require quantifiable evidence to prevent misuse and maintain constitutional balance.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the necessity of data-driven reservation policies.

Case Name: Gian Kaur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Section 306 IPC, which criminalizes abetment of suicide, violates the right to life.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that the right to life under Article 21 should extend to the right to end one's life, making the penal provision on abetment of suicide invalid.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court struck down Section 306 IPC as unconstitutional, reasoning that penalizing abetment of suicide contradicts the fundamental right to life.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that denying an individual the choice to end their life violates fundamental rights and personal autonomy.
Rules: The State has the authority to regulate acts that threaten life, including suicide.
Precedent: P. Rathinam case, which questioned the criminalization of suicide.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that the right to life is about the protection of life and does not extend to its voluntary termination.
Ruling: The Supreme Court overruled the P. Rathinam case and held that suicide and its abetment can be criminalized without violating fundamental rights.

Case Name: K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) Vs. Union of India (Aadhaar Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory Aadhaar requirement infringes upon individual privacy rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that requiring Aadhaar for services such as banking, taxation, and welfare schemes constituted excessive state surveillance and data collection.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that Aadhaar’s mandatory linking was justified under national security and public welfare considerations.
Argument: Aadhaar linkage undermines personal liberty, exposes individuals to data misuse, and infringes on autonomy.
Rules: Right to Privacy as an intrinsic part of Article 21.
Precedent: Decisions on personal liberty, data protection, and surveillance concerns.
Ratio of the Decision: Privacy is a fundamental right, but certain restrictions are permissible in the interest of national security and welfare distribution.
Ruling: Aadhaar is constitutional but cannot be made compulsory for services like bank accounts, telecom services, and school admissions.

Case Name: Shayara Bano Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the practice of instant triple talaq violates fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner claimed that instant triple talaq left Muslim women vulnerable to sudden and unilateral divorce, violating equality and dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that instant triple talaq was valid under religious law and protected.
Argument: The petitioner argued that triple talaq was arbitrary, unfair, and placed Muslim women at a disadvantage compared to women of other religions.
Rules: Fundamental rights and protections for gender equality.
Precedent: Cases on women's rights and protection under personal laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Religious practices cannot override fundamental rights, and instant triple talaq is discriminatory.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that instant triple talaq is unconstitutional and not protected under religious freedom.

Case Name: Common Cause Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether passive euthanasia and living wills should be legally recognized.
Facts of the Case: The case challenged the legal framework surrounding end-of-life care and patient autonomy in refusing life support.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that passive euthanasia was not explicitly recognized under Indian law.
Argument: The right to die with dignity is an extension of the fundamental right to life under Article 21.
Rules: Legal principles governing medical consent and right to refuse treatment.
Precedent: Previous cases on medical autonomy and end-of-life decisions.
Ratio of the Decision: Passive euthanasia must be allowed under strict guidelines to ensure ethical medical decision-making.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that individuals can refuse life support, allowing passive euthanasia under strict conditions.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Kamal Nath
Issue Presented: Legality of diverting natural resources for private commercial purposes.
Facts of the Case: A resort project caused significant ecological harm, leading to a legal challenge over environmental conservation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court penalized the developers but did not halt the project.
Argument: The development project led to deforestation and river pollution, violating sustainability norms.
Rules: Public Trust Doctrine ensuring protection of natural resources.
Precedent: Judicial precedents affirming the state’s role as a trustee of natural resources.
Ratio of the Decision: The government is responsible for safeguarding ecological balance and preventing misuse of environmental assets.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of environmental protection, directing corrective measures to restore ecological balance.

Case Name: State of Tamil Nadu Vs. K. Balu
Issue Presented: Legality of restricting liquor sales near highways for public safety reasons.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that unrestricted liquor sales along highways led to reckless driving and fatal accidents.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of state policies, rejecting a blanket ban.
Argument: The state failed to regulate alcohol consumption near highways, leading to preventable accidents.
Rules: Liquor Laws and Road Safety Policies.
Precedent: Legal precedents emphasizing state responsibility in regulating alcohol distribution.
Ratio of the Decision: The government has a duty to restrict activities that endanger public welfare.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of road safety, restricting liquor sales along highways to prevent accidents.

Case Name: Delhi Transport Corporation Vs. DTC Mazdoor Congress
Issue Presented: Legality of arbitrary termination of employees without fair procedure.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner terminated employees arbitrarily without due process, prompting legal action.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the dismissal was unlawful and ordered reinstatement.
Argument: DTC argued that employee termination was part of administrative control and did not require elaborate procedures.
Rules: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Precedent: Judicial decisions emphasizing procedural fairness in employment termination.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to livelihood is constitutionally protected, and termination must adhere to procedural fairness.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the dismissals violated principles of fairness and ordered reinstatement.

Case Name: State of Uttar Pradesh Vs. Raj Narain
Issue Presented: The extent to which government transparency is mandated under the right to information.
Facts of the Case: A legal challenge was raised regarding the government's refusal to disclose election-related documents, citing confidentiality.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the respondent, stating that government information affecting public interest must be accessible.
Argument: The petitioner argued that disclosing sensitive government documents could compromise administrative integrity.
Rules: Right to Information Act, transparency regulations, and previous legal precedents.
Precedent: Landmark rulings on freedom of information and government accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: Public access to governmental documents is fundamental to accountability and democracy.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of public access, emphasizing the need for transparency in governance.

Case Name: M. Nagaraj Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: The constitutional validity of reservation in promotions and whether it affects meritocracy.
Facts of the Case: The case questioned whether reservations in promotions needed to be backed by quantifiable data proving backwardness.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the government, allowing reservations in promotions.
Argument: The petitioner argued that blanket reservations in promotions undermine efficiency and merit-based advancements.
Rules: Legal provisions governing affirmative action and reservation in promotions.
Precedent: Previous cases that addressed the implementation of reservations in government employment.
Ratio of the Decision: Affirmative action must be balanced with constitutional equality and efficiency in administration.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that reservations in promotions are valid but subject to proving backwardness with empirical data.

Case Name: Joseph Shine Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: The constitutional validity of adultery laws and whether they infringe upon gender equality and personal liberty.
Facts of the Case: The case challenged the outdated adultery law, which only punished men and denied women autonomy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that adultery remained a criminal offense under the existing law.
Argument: The law is based on patriarchal notions and treats women as subordinate to men.
Rules: Constitutional protections against gender-based discrimination and violation of personal liberty.
Precedent: Landmark judgments on gender justice and personal autonomy.
Ratio of the Decision: The state cannot impose moral codes through discriminatory laws.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that adultery is a private matter and cannot be criminalized.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: The constitutionality of TADA and whether it infringes upon personal liberty.
Facts of the Case: TADA allowed preventive detention and special courts, raising concerns over due process.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that TADA was necessary for national security but acknowledged concerns over misuse.
Argument: The law undermines fundamental rights by restricting legal safeguards for accused persons.
Rules: Articles 14 and 21, ensuring equality before the law and protection of life and personal liberty.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on preventive detention and national security laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The need for counterterrorism laws must be balanced with constitutional safeguards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court maintained TADA’s validity but recommended additional safeguards.

Case Name: Nandini Satpathy Vs. P.L. Dani
Issue Presented: Whether compelling an accused to answer questions during interrogation violates Article 20(3).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, a former Chief Minister, was asked multiple questions during an investigation, which she declined to answer, citing constitutional protections.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the petitioner was obligated to answer unless the questions were explicitly self-incriminating.
Argument: The interrogation process should respect constitutional protections, and no accused should be compelled to self-incriminate.
Rules: Fundamental right against self-incrimination and due process protections.
Precedent: Judicial interpretations of self-incrimination under Indian and international law.
Ratio of the Decision: The right against self-incrimination is absolute and must be safeguarded during interrogations.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that Article 20(3) protects individuals from being forced to testify against themselves during police investigations.

Case Name: Sarla Mudgal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legality of conversion to Islam for the sole purpose of practicing polygamy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the act of men converting to Islam solely to enter a second marriage without dissolving the first.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the man, stating that religious conversion legally allowed polygamy.
Argument: Such conversions should not be recognized if they are done with the sole intent of practicing polygamy.
Rules: The legal framework governing personal laws and marriage.
Precedent: Cases on bigamy and religious conversions for the purpose of marriage.
Ratio of the Decision: A man cannot convert solely for the purpose of practicing polygamy while evading his obligations under the Hindu Marriage Act.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared that a Hindu marriage subsists even after conversion, making the second marriage void.

Case Name: Visakha Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Legal vacuum regarding workplace sexual harassment laws.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed to demand legal safeguards against workplace sexual harassment after an incident of sexual violence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the plea due to a lack of existing laws on workplace harassment.
Argument: Lack of legal provisions does not absolve the state from ensuring workplace safety for women.
Rules: The need for judicially framed guidelines in the absence of a statute.
Precedent: Absence of a legal framework necessitating judicial intervention.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights necessitate protections against harassment even without explicit legislation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court framed the Vishaka Guidelines, mandating workplace protections for women until formal legislation was enacted.

Case Name: Bachan Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the death penalty violates the fundamental rights under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: Bachan Singh, convicted of murder, argued that capital punishment was cruel and violated the right to life.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of retaining the death penalty.
Argument: Capital punishment deprives individuals of their fundamental right to life and should be unconstitutional.
Rules: The principle of judicial discretion in awarding capital punishment.
Precedent: Judicial interpretations of the death penalty in India.
Ratio of the Decision: The death penalty should only be awarded when the crime is of extreme brutality and societal impact.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that while the death penalty is valid, it must only be imposed in extraordinary circumstances.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Dalbir Singh
Issue Presented: Challenge to the mandatory death penalty under the NDPS Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was sentenced to death under the NDPS Act, which mandated capital punishment for specific drug offenses. He argued that this provision infringed on fundamental rights and the principles of fair sentencing.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the provision, affirming its constitutionality.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that mandatory death sentences do not allow for case-by-case judicial assessment and violate constitutional protections. The state maintained that the law was crucial for controlling drug-related crimes.
Rules: Sentencing proportionality and constitutional safeguards under Article 21.
Precedent: Bachan Singh case, which emphasized individualized sentencing in capital cases.
Ratio of the Decision: Judicial discretion is essential in capital punishment cases to ensure fairness.
Ruling: The Supreme Court invalidated the mandatory death sentence provision, emphasizing the need for judicial assessment in capital cases.

Case Name: State (Delhi Administration) Vs. Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Another
Respondent: Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Ram Kishan Alias Phokan
Issue Presented: Whether the acquittal by the High Court was justified based on the evidence presented.
Facts of the Case: Phokan, armed with a knife, attempted to flee and called out to Billa. The Delhi High Court acquitted the accused citing a lack of sufficient evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court nullified the conviction and acquitted the accused.
Argument: Argued that the evidence was insufficient to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, thereby rendering the acquittal erroneous.
Rules: Conviction for murder necessitates conclusive evidence beyond a reasonable doubt.
Precedent: No explicit precedent was cited.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court determined that the evidence sufficiently established the respondents' guilt, and that the acquittal was a judicial error.
Ruling: The Supreme Court reversed the acquittal, convicting the accused under Section 326 IPC and sentencing them to six years of rigorous imprisonment.

Case Name: Ram Saran Dass Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the termination order, being a disguised dismissal issued in bad faith, necessitates constitutional protection.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s services were terminated, and he contended that this termination equated to punishment without the due process required by law.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court summarily dismissed the petition.
Argument: The petitioner argued that his termination constituted a de facto dismissal.
Rules: Service Rule 23 governing termination of employment.
Precedent: Established precedents emphasizing the need for procedural fairness and due process in employment dismissals.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court determined that natural justice mandates that the respondent be given an opportunity to respond before any dismissal is finalized.
Ruling: The appeal was allowed, with the case remanded so that the respondent could present its case.

Case Name: Credit Agricole Indosuez Vs. Credential Finance Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the non-crediting of a cheque after clearance qualifies as grounds for winding up under the Companies Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, a banking institution, maintained the respondent’s account, yet the cheque amount remained uncredited after clearance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The petition for winding up was dismissed by the lower court.
Argument: It was contended that the cheque’s non-crediting resulted from valid and justifiable reasons, and therefore did not automatically establish an inability to pay debts.
Rules: Judicial guidelines concerning the proper crediting of cheques and the financial obligations of companies.
Precedent: Cited case law on cheque clearance and corporate insolvency matters.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision turns on whether not crediting a cheque post-clearance implies an inability to pay debts under statutory requirements.
Ruling: Appeal filed; further hearings required.

Case Name: A.K. Gopalan Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Challenge to the constitutionality of preventive detention, questioning if it infringes Article 21 rights.
Facts of the Case: Gopalan was detained under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, and contended that his detention, absent a fair trial, violated his constitutional rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court supported the legality of detention under the Act.
Argument: The petitioner contended that denying a fair trial in preventive detention cases breached the constitutional guarantee.
Rules: The protection of Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: No specific precedent was cited regarding preventive detention.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision held that preventive detention is permissible provided that it complies with procedural safeguards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the Act’s validity while later judicial interpretations expanded the scope.

Case Name: State of West Bengal Vs. Anwar Ali Sarkar
Issue Presented: Examining if the use of special courts undermines the right to equality as guaranteed under Article 14.
Facts of the Case: A law enabling the government to refer cases to special courts was challenged by the petitioner, who argued that this practice.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against the law, deeming it discriminatory in nature.
Argument: It was argued by the petitioner that referring cases only to special courts was discriminatory and breached the equality principles enshrined in Article 14.
Rules: Principles of equality before the law and fair procedural processes.
Precedent: Precedents addressing special courts and non-discriminatory practices.
Ratio of the Decision: It was held that the structure and operation of special courts must adhere to uniform legal principles and cannot be arbitrary.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ultimately invalidated the law, ruling it unconstitutional.

Case Name: Kedar Nath Singh Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: The extent to which sedition laws under Section 124A conflict with the right to free speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, after making speeches critical of government policies, was convicted under Section 124A IPC for sedition.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained the conviction under Section 124A.
Argument: The petitioner argued that sedition laws unduly limit freedom of expression and should not penalize mere criticism of government policies.
Rules: Protection of free speech subject to reasonable restrictions as laid down by the law.
Precedent: Earlier decisions on sedition that clarified the boundaries of permissible free expression.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision established that mere criticism does not constitute sedition unless accompanied by incitement to violence.
Ruling: The Supreme Court confirmed the validity of Section 124A while narrowing its scope to cases involving speech that incites violence.

Case Name: Bharat Singh Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether the acquisition of land is valid under the requirement that it must serve a bona fide public purpose.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner disputed the acquisition of his agricultural land on the grounds that it did not serve a public purpose as required by law.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court affirmed the validity of the land acquisition.
Argument: The petitioner argued that his property rights were infringed upon because the acquisition lacked genuine public purpose and did not offer fair compensation.
Rules: The legal requirement that land acquisition must serve a public purpose and be paired with just compensation.
Precedent: Previous decisions on land acquisition which established that only acquisitions for a legitimate public purpose with fair compensation are valid.
Ratio of the Decision: Acquisition of land is lawful only if it fulfills the requirement of a legitimate public purpose.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the government's acquisition decision.

Case Name: Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the NJAC Act violates the principle of judicial independence enshrined in the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The NJAC Act, designed to reform the judicial appointment process, was contested as it allegedly encroached upon the autonomy of the judiciary.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld NJAC as valid.
Argument: The petitioner argued that by increasing the executive’s role in judicial appointments, the NJAC Act compromised the separation of powers and the essential independence of the judiciary.
Rules: Constitutional norms regarding judicial appointments.
Precedent: Earlier decisions that reinforced the necessity of preserving judicial independence.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision established that judicial independence is a fundamental principle that must not be compromised by executive influence.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ultimately struck down the NJAC Act as unconstitutional.

Case Name: Laxmi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the regulation of acid sales and the measures for protecting acid attack victims are adequate under existing law.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner filed a PIL seeking comprehensive reforms including tighter controls on acid sales and enhanced compensation and rehabilitation for acid attack victims.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court advised stricter enforcement of current acid sale regulations.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the easy accessibility of acid results in numerous attacks and that existing support systems for victims are inadequate.
Rules: Provisions regulating acid sales and the rehabilitation and compensation of acid attack survivors.
Precedent: Earlier cases on women's safety that underscore the necessity for robust preventive measures.
Ratio of the Decision: The availability of acid must be tightly controlled to prevent attacks and ensure proper support and compensation for victims.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered restrictions on acid sales and better compensation for victims.

Case Name: Tamil Nadu Govt. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: The extent of central government authority over education policies, and whether such laws infringe on the states’ powers under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Tamil Nadu Govt. questioned the validity of central laws on education, asserting that such laws adversely affected the state’s ability to independently formulate education policies.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court favored the central government, finding that the laws did not breach constitutional limits on state powers.
Argument: The petitioner contended that education falls under state jurisdiction, and central laws overreaching into this domain disturb the federal balance.
Rules: Focused on the constitutional allocation of powers, especially the balance between state autonomy.
Precedent: Prior cases on federalism and education were examined to determine the permissible scope of central intervention in state matters.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized that education policy can involve both state and central inputs.
Ruling: The Supreme Court confirmed the validity of the central laws on education.

Case Name: Subramanian Swamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: The constitutional validity of criminal defamation laws in light of free speech protections.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the validity of Sections 499 and 500 IPC, argThe petitioner contested that the criminal defamation provisions in Sections 499 and 500 IPC impose excessive limitations on free speech.uing that they restricted free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that criminal defamation laws were constitutional.
Argument: The petitioner argued that issues of defamation should be resolved through civil remedies, not criminal prosecution.
Rules: Protection of free speech under Article 19(1)(a) of the Indian Constitution.
Precedent: Prior rulings that examined the balance between reputation and freedom of expression in defamation cases.
Ratio of the Decision: The court held that although reputation is a significant right, the imposition of criminal sanctions for defamation is a justifiable limitation on free speech under the constitutional framework.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ultimately upheld the criminal defamation provisions as constitutional.

Case Name: Ram Jawaya Kapur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: The extent of executive power under the Constitution, particularly regarding business operations without explicit legislative authorization.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner asserted that the Punjab government was acting beyond its scope by operating a business without proper legislative sanction.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the government’s action, holding that the executive has certain discretionary powers in areas not explicitly covered by legislation.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the executive’s unilateral business operations should require legislative oversight.
Rules: The principle that executive authority is subject to legislative limits as per the doctrine of separation of powers.
Precedent: Prior rulings on the limits of executive power were considered in evaluating whether the government’s action exceeded its bounds.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that executive power can extend to unregulated areas.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the validity of the government’s action and outlined that executive power.

Case Name: State of Bihar Vs. K.K. Misra
Issue Presented: Examination of the right of government employees to strike, especially considering restrictions in essential services.
Facts of the Case: A strike by government employees for better wages resulted in disciplinary action, prompting the legal challenge.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the employees, finding the strike justified under the circumstances.
Argument: It was argued by the petitioner that the right to strike is not absolute for government employees.
Rules: Essential Services Maintenance Act.
Precedent: Earlier rulings addressing restrictions on the right to strike for government employees.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling held that the right to strike for government employees is subject to restrictions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld restrictions on strikes, ruling against the employees’ claim of an absolute right to strike.

Case Name: Sundararamier & Co. Vs. State of Andhra Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether state taxation of inter-state trade violates constitutional provisions.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner challenged the state's authority to impose sales tax on inter-state transactions, citing constitutional restrictions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the state taxation law as valid.
Argument: Petitioner argued that inter-state commerce taxation falls exclusively within Parliament’s jurisdiction.
Rules: Inter-state taxation should align with constitutional principles governing commerce and trade.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions on state taxation of inter-state commerce.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling reinforced the constitutional limits on state taxation over inter-state trade.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled against the state, emphasizing that inter-state taxation is solely under Parliament's jurisdiction.

Case Name: Golak Nath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Can constitutional amendments limit fundamental rights?
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that amendments affecting fundamental rights violate the Constitution.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Parliamentâ€™s power to amend fundamental rights.
Argument: Constitutional amendments should not alter fundamental rights.
Rules: Doctrine of implied limitations.
Precedent: No explicit precedent restricting amendment powers.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights are essential to constitutional integrity.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled against Parliament’s unrestricted amendment power, later refined in Kesavananda Bharati case.

Case Name: Shankarappa Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Validity of censorship imposed on films.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that denial of certification infringed on artistic freedom and free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that film censorship was justified.
Argument: Censorship laws should not restrict creative expression arbitrarily.
Rules: Film censorship regulations under constitutional law.
Precedent: Prior Supreme Court rulings on artistic freedom.
Ratio of the Decision: Film censorship should be justified on constitutional grounds.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that censorship must align with constitutional rights.

Case Name: Madhu Limaye Vs. Sub-Divisional Magistrate
Issue Presented: Constitutional validity and misuse of Section 144 CrPC.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner argued that imposing Section 144 for prolonged periods curtailed democratic rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that the government has the authority to impose Section 144 when necessary.
Argument: The provision allows excessive executive control, undermining fundamental rights.
Rules: Constitutional provisions on free speech and public order.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court cases on executive powers in law enforcement.
Ratio of the Decision: The use of Section 144 must balance public safety with democratic freedoms.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that prolonged use of Section 144 is unconstitutional.

Case Name: Rupa Ashok Hurra Vs. Ashok Hurra
Issue Presented: The legal validity and scope of curative petitions in the judicial system.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner challenged judicial finality, arguing for an additional mechanism to correct grave errors.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed the petition, affirming that Supreme Court decisions are final.
Argument: Supreme Court must have a corrective process beyond review petitions for extraordinary cases.
Rules: Supreme Court's power to review its own decisions in exceptional cases.
Precedent: Judicial rulings affirming the Supreme Court’s authority to correct its own mistakes.
Ratio of the Decision: Judicial finality must be balanced with mechanisms to prevent miscarriages of justice.
Ruling: Supreme Court established curative petitions as a remedy for cases of significant judicial oversight.

Case Name: Shyam Narayan Chouksey Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legal and constitutional validity of enforcing national anthem in cinemas.
Facts of the Case: The plea sought enforcement of mandatory anthem playing in theaters to encourage respect for national symbols.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court rejected the plea, stating that respect for the anthem should not be enforced through legal compulsion.
Argument: National unity and respect for the anthem are fundamental civic duties, justifying mandatory enforcement.
Statute: Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971.
Rules: National symbols must be respected, but their enforcement should align with constitutional freedoms.
Precedent: Prior judgments on constitutional limits of patriotism enforcement.
Ratio of the Decision: While national symbols should be honored, enforcement must not violate individual freedoms.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that playing the national anthem is encouraged but should not be legally imposed.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N.M. Thomas
Issue Presented: Legality of extending reservations to promotions under Article 16(4).
Facts of the Case: A government policy granting reservations in promotions was contested as unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court struck down the policy as exceeding constitutional provisions.
Argument: Reservations in promotions are necessary to ensure equitable representation of SC/ST employees.
Rules: Constitutional provisions allowing affirmative action in employment.
Precedent: Prior judgments on reservation policies and equality principles.
Ratio of the Decision: Affirmative action in promotions must be balanced with efficiency in public administration.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed reservations in promotions, subject to reasonable justification.

Case Name: Vishwanath Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Interpretation of Section 304B IPC and burden of proof.
Facts of the Case: The deceased's family alleged dowry harassment before her death, prompting a legal case.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the prosecution, citing strong circumstantial evidence.
Argument: Conviction cannot be based solely on presumption; direct proof is necessary.
Rules: Legal framework on dowry-related offenses.
Precedent: Previous cases interpreting Section 304B and its evidentiary requirements.
Ratio of the Decision: Courts must carefully assess evidence before convicting under dowry death provisions.
Ruling: Supreme Court maintained the conviction while stressing fair application of burden of proof.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Ganga Pollution Case)
Issue Presented: Accountability of industries and government in pollution control.
Facts of the Case: Industries and municipalities were discharging untreated waste into the Ganga, leading to severe contamination.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court issued guidelines but did not take strict enforcement actions.
Argument: Industrial pollution laws were not being effectively implemented, leading to environmental degradation.
Rules: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974.
Precedent: Prior cases emphasizing sustainable development and pollution control.
Ratio of the Decision: Polluting industries must comply with environmental regulations or face closure.
Ruling: Supreme Court enforced stringent regulations, ordering industries to install pollution control measures.

Case Name: Govind Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh
Issue Presented: Right to privacy versus law enforcement powers.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was placed under continuous police surveillance without clear justification.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the surveillance, citing law and order concerns.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the right to privacy is implicit in Article 21 and surveillance should be limited.
Rules: Fundamental rights and police powers.
Precedent: Privacy must be balanced with law enforcement needs, but excessive surveillance is unconstitutional.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court ruled that surveillance must be justified and cannot be arbitrary.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld limited surveillance while emphasizing the need for safeguards.

Case Name: Indian Medical Association Vs. V.P. Shantha
Issue Presented: Can medical professionals be held liable under consumer laws?
Facts of the Case: A patient alleged medical malpractice and filed a complaint under consumer law.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that medical services fell under the Consumer Protection Act.
Argument: Petitioner contended that medical services involve personal skill and judgment, not a commercial service.
Rules: Rights of consumers in availing professional services.
Precedent: Prior rulings on the applicability of consumer law to medical services.
Ratio of the Decision: Medical services are subject to consumer laws if provided for consideration.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that medical professionals can be held accountable under consumer laws.

Case Name: People Union for Democratic Rights Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Can the state be held accountable for failing to enforce labor protections?
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that laborers were not being paid minimum wages or given proper working conditions during the Asiad Games projects.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found lapses in implementation but stopped short of ordering strict enforcement.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that laborers’ rights were being systematically ignored, violating fundamental rights.
Rules: Right to fair wages and working conditions.
Precedent: Past rulings on workers' welfare and employment protections.
Ratio of the Decision: Workers’ rights cannot be ignored, and non-enforcement of laws violates fundamental rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that failure to implement labor protections was unconstitutional.

Case Name: Ramesh Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Can the state ban television content that allegedly incites hatred?
Facts of the Case: A petition sought restrictions on a serial that was accused of fueling communal tensions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that the show was protected under free speech and did not mandate censorship.
Argument: The petitioner argued that allowing such content would exacerbate communal tensions and lead to unrest.
Rules: Balance between artistic expression and societal harmony.
Precedent: Past rulings on media regulation and permissible speech restrictions.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to broadcast must be protected but subject to reasonable restrictions when necessary.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the TV serial but allowed monitoring for objectionable content.

Case Name: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. Vs. State of Rajasthan and Others
Issue Presented: Determination of whether freight charges should be included in the taxable sale price of cement under the Cement Control Order.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, operating Udaipur Cement Works in Rajasthan, was selling cement both within and outside Rajasthan under a government-controlled pricing scheme.
Ruling by Lower Court: The authorities included freight charges in the sale price, thereby making them subject to sales tax.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that freight was a separate charge borne by the buyer and should not be included in the taxable amount.
Statute: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, 1954.
Rules: Examination of "sale price" under taxation laws in cases where government price control applies.
Precedent: Cases analyzing the inclusion of freight costs in taxable sale prices under government-controlled pricing models.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether freight charges should be considered an integral part of the sale price for tax purposes.
Ruling: The court was set to determine if freight should be excluded from the taxable price of cement.

Case Name: R.G. Anand Vs. Delux Films
Issue Presented: Whether substantial similarities in theme, characters, and storyline amount to copyright infringement.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner claimed that the respondent’s film closely resembled his theatrical play in theme and expression.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court found that while there were similarities, they were not significant enough to prove plagiarism.
