Argument: The petitioner asserted that the film contained significant elements derived from his original work, violating copyright law.
Rules: The principle of originality in copyright law and the extent to which general themes can be protected.
Precedent: Cases discussing copyright in literary and artistic works, particularly where general themes are involved.
Ratio of the Decision: Broad themes are not protected by copyright unless substantial and verbatim copying is proven.
Ruling: The Supreme Court rejected the petitioner’s claim, emphasizing that ideas and themes are not copyrightable only specific expressions are.

Case Name: Shri Roshanlal Gautam Vs. State Of Uttar Pradesh And Others
Respondent: State of Uttar Pradesh and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the government had the authority to nationalize private transport services in the state.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner operated under a contract carriage permit in Agra and challenged the state's decision to revoke private transport permits.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the state, stating that it had the right to regulate and nationalize transport routes.
Argument: Argued that the State Government exceeded its authority by revoking permits without consent.
Statute: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 1956.
Rules: Interpretation of Section 68-C and its role in state-controlled transport services.
Precedent: Cases dealing with state intervention in transport services and the revocation of private permits.
Ratio of the Decision: The court examined whether nationalization of transport services was in line with legislative intent and the public interest.
Ruling: The Supreme Court was yet to rule on the validity of the state’s decision.

Case Name: P. Rathinam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 309 IPC, which criminalizes attempted suicide, violates the right to life.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that criminalizing attempted suicide was an infringement on personal liberty and dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court maintained that the state had an interest in preserving life and upheld the penal provision.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that the right to life should also include the right to die, making Section 309 unconstitutional.
Statute: The scope of Article 21 and its application to personal autonomy in life and death decisions.
Rules: The scope of Article 21 and its application to personal autonomy in life and death decisions.
Precedent: Cases interpreting the balance between individual rights and state interest in regulating suicide.
Ratio of the Decision: The court reasoned that allowing the right to die could have social and legal consequences, necessitating state intervention.
Ruling: The Supreme Court’s later ruling in Gian Kaur upheld Section 309, reinforcing that the right to life does not imply a right to die.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the financial distribution between the center and state was just and constitutional.
Facts of the Case: The Karnataka government contended that the central government’s financial policies unfairly limited state resources.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the central government’s policy, stating that financial allocations were made per constitutional guidelines.
Argument: Karnataka claimed that the central government’s financial policies disproportionately disadvantaged certain states.
Rules: Principles of fiscal federalism and the constitutional allocation of financial resources.
Precedent: Cases discussing the balance of financial powers between central and state governments.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment emphasized the need for a balanced financial distribution system to maintain cooperative federalism.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the central government while advising a more transparent and equitable allocation process.

Case Name: Rajbala Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Challenge to the Haryana Panchayati Raj (Amendment) Act mandating educational qualifications for local body elections.
Facts of the Case: The amendment established minimum literacy requirements for candidates contesting Panchayat elections, affecting a significant portion of rural aspirants. Petitioners argued it was arbitrary.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the challenge, affirming that states had the right to impose reasonable restrictions on electoral eligibility.
Argument: The petitioners contended that the amendment violated Article 14 by disproportionately affecting women and economically weaker candidates.
Rules: Judicial principles concerning reasonable restrictions on electoral rights.
Precedent: Cases addressing legislative competence in regulating electoral eligibility.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court found that educational qualifications serve a legitimate state interest in improving governance.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that educational qualifications for Panchayat elections are constitutional, provided they serve a legitimate purpose.

Case Name: Municipal Board, Manglaur Vs. Sri Mahadeoji Maharaj
Issue Presented: Legal determination of ownership of land adjacent to a public road whether it vested in the Municipality or remained private property.
Facts of the Case: The Municipality planned construction on a vacant piece of land adjoining a public road. The respondent claimed ownership, asserting the land was never transferred to the Municipality.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court determined that the Municipality had no legal claim over the land and ruled in favor of the respondent.
Argument: The Municipality maintained that under municipal governance laws, adjacent vacant land naturally vests in the Municipality.
Statute: Local governance laws regulating municipal land ownership.
Rules: Interpretation of land acquisition and governance statutes.
Precedent: Case law addressing municipal authority over public spaces and adjacent land.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court examined whether the Municipality had acquired the land through legal means or if it remained privately owned.
Ruling: Supreme Court to decide whether the Municipality’s claim is valid under existing municipal governance laws.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. Association for Democratic Reforms
Issue Presented: Legal obligation of candidates to disclose criminal backgrounds and financial details before elections.
Facts of the Case: A public interest litigation (PIL) was filed arguing that voters had the right to access information about candidates’ backgrounds before elections.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that candidates must disclose their criminal records and assets for an informed electorate.
Argument: The government argued that compelling candidates to disclose their personal details infringed on their privacy, while the respondent emphasized electoral fairness and voter awareness.
Rules: Legal principles surrounding election transparency and privacy rights.
Precedent: Cases addressing voter rights and access to candidate information.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling focused on whether disclosure of criminal records and financial details was a reasonable requirement under election laws.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision, affirming that transparency in elections is essential to democracy.

Case Name: Jindal Stainless Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Legality of entry tax under Article 301 and its impact on interstate commerce.
Facts of the Case: The case examined whether states had the authority to levy entry tax without violating the principle of free movement of goods across state borders.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the state's authority, stating that taxation was a fiscal measure that did not automatically violate free trade principles.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that the tax created an unfair burden on businesses operating across state lines, while the state maintained that taxation was necessary for revenue generation and regulation.
Rules: Interstate commerce laws and taxation policies.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on state taxation and economic barriers.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court analyzed the balance between unrestricted trade and a state’s fiscal autonomy.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that states could impose entry tax as long as it did not create barriers to trade.

Case Name: M/S Japan Airlines Co. Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Respondent: Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Issue Presented: Applicability of TDS on landing and parking charges at airports.
Facts of the Case: The airline contested the classification of airport charges as rent, arguing that such fees were for services rather than for leasing land.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the tax authorities, stating that the charges were linked to the use of land.
Argument: The airline contended that airport fees covered operational services rather than renting airport land.
Statute: Section 194-I of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
Rules: Taxation rules regarding deductions at source for payments related to land usage.
Precedent: Judicial decisions on the classification of operational fees as taxable rent.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized the distinction between service fees and rent for tax purposes.
Ruling: Awaiting a ruling from the Supreme Court.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Jagjit Singh
Issue Presented: Right of temporary workers to claim salary parity with regular employees.
Facts of the Case: The case involved a contractual government worker demanding salary equivalence with permanent staff.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court held that temporary employees performing the same duties as regular staff should receive equal compensation.
Argument: The petitioner argued that employment status justifies pay differentiation, regardless of job responsibilities.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 14 & Directive Principles of State Policy.
Rules: Legal standards governing wage parity in public sector employment.
Precedent: Judicial decisions interpreting wage laws for temporary workers.
Ratio of the Decision: The nature of work, not the form of employment, determines wage entitlement.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the respondent, emphasizing that temporary employees cannot be paid less for the same work.

Case Name: Kailas & Others Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: The legality and severity of punishment for honor killings.
Facts of the Case: A group of individuals was charged with the murder of a couple in an honor killing, with arguments over the appropriateness of the sentence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court rejected arguments for leniency and confirmed that honor killings amount to murder.
Argument: The defense contended that honor killings should be viewed in light of societal norms and not equated with ordinary murders.
Rules: Application of criminal statutes in cases of honor-based violence.
Precedent: Cases reinforcing strict punishment for crimes committed under the guise of social honor.
Ratio of the Decision: No cultural or traditional justification can mitigate criminal liability in honor killings.
Ruling: The Supreme Court confirmed the life sentence, stating that such crimes must be treated with the strictest penalties.

Case Name: Krishna Pillai Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Whether smuggling gold from Pondicherry without authorization justifies a conviction under customs law.
Facts of the Case: The accused was caught transporting gold illegally across state borders and confessed, leading to legal proceedings.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled against the accused, holding that the confession and material evidence warranted conviction.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the confession should not automatically lead to punishment without corroborating evidence.
Statute: Section 7(1)(b) of the Land Customs Act, 1924.
Rules: The transportation of dutiable goods without clearance is a punishable offense.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the admissibility of confessions in smuggling cases.
Ratio of the Decision: Smuggling of gold without customs clearance is punishable, though the legitimacy of confessions must be evaluated.
Ruling: The High Court upheld the conviction but ruled that the manner of obtaining the confession required scrutiny.

Case Name: State of Rajasthan Vs. Jagannath
Issue Presented: Whether land encroachment by private individuals justifies eviction under state land laws.
Facts of the Case: The state accused the respondent of unlawfully settling on public land, sparking legal action.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court held that illegal land occupation must be removed and ruled against the respondent.
Argument: The petitioner argued that unauthorized settlement violates land protection laws.
Rules: Unauthorized land occupation is subject to removal as per state land laws.
Precedent: Previous judgments addressing illegal occupation of public land.
Ratio of the Decision: Illegal encroachments should be removed, but fair relocation policies must be enforced.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of eviction while ensuring rehabilitation for affected individuals.

Case Name: National Legal Services Authority Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the legal recognition of transgender persons as a third gender should be implemented.
Facts of the Case: The PIL challenged the lack of legal recognition for transgender individuals under existing laws.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court ruled in favor of the recognition of transgender persons but deferred implementation details.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the lack of legal recognition for transgender individuals was a breach of their constitutional rights.
Rules: The legal status of transgender persons must be recognized, with appropriate laws enacted.
Precedent: Past decisions addressing the rights of marginalized groups and equality before the law.
Ratio of the Decision: Transgender persons must be recognized as a third gender with rights to education, employment, and social services.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of recognizing transgender individuals as a third gender and called for policy changes.

Case Name: Mithu Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of imposing a mandatory death sentence for life convicts committing murder.
Facts of the Case: The law mandated a death penalty for life convicts committing murder, which was argued to be unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that the provision was legally valid and served a protective purpose.
Argument: The argument was that automatic capital punishment deprived the judiciary of discretion, leading to unfair sentencing.
Rules: A law that removes judicial discretion violates fundamental rights.
Precedent: Cases supporting the principle that courts must consider circumstances before imposing a death sentence.
Ratio of the Decision: The absence of judicial discretion in sentencing makes Section 303 IPC unconstitutional.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled Section 303 IPC unconstitutional, stating that mandatory death sentencing is arbitrary.

Case Name: D.K. Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether the lack of procedural safeguards enables unchecked police brutality.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner cited numerous cases of police brutality in custody and requested judicial intervention for systemic reforms.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court recognized the problem and recommended police accountability measures but did not enforce new laws.
Argument: The argument was that detainees’ fundamental rights were routinely violated due to a lack of strict arrest and custody procedures.
Rules: Any form of torture or inhumane treatment violates constitutional rights.
Precedent: Cases reinforcing the need for procedural safeguards against police abuse.
Ratio of the Decision: The judiciary has a duty to enforce safeguards to prevent police excesses and ensure accountability.
Ruling: Supreme Court issued strict protocols to prevent torture and unlawful detentions.

Case Name: Ajay Hasia Vs. Khalid Mujib Sehravardi
Issue Presented: Whether institutions receiving substantial state funding are bound by fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the admission policies of an institute that received significant government aid, arguing it should be considered 'State.'
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that private institutions, even if funded by the government, do not automatically fall under Article 12.
Argument: The argument was that financial and administrative control by the government brings an institution within the definition of 'State.'
Rules: If an institution is heavily funded and managed by the government, it is bound by constitutional obligations.
Precedent: Cases determining the scope of 'State' under Article 12 for institutions with government involvement.
Ratio of the Decision: Government-aided and managed institutions cannot violate fundamental rights as they function in a public capacity.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that the institution, due to its government funding and administrative influence, fell under Article 12.

Case Name: Narmada Bachao Andolan Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the environmental and rehabilitation concerns raised by the petitioners were sufficient to halt the dam’s construction.
Facts of the Case: The petitioners argued that the dam violated environmental laws and human rights, displacing tribal communities without proper rehabilitation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the dam's construction, emphasizing the government’s commitment to rehabilitation.
Argument: The dam led to human rights violations, and rehabilitation efforts were inadequate.
Rules: Government projects must balance economic development with social justice.
Precedent: Cases where development vs. environment conflicts were resolved in favor of national growth.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether rehabilitation measures were sufficient to justify the dam's construction.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the project but stressed the need for better resettlement policies.

Case Name: The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Vs. S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Respondent: S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether remittances to foreign corporations by S. K. F. were profits of the agent and therefore taxable.
Facts of the Case: S. K. F. acted as a selling agent for foreign corporations and remitted the proceeds under an agreement.
Ruling by Lower Court: Held that remittances made after realization of sales were subject to tax, while those made beforehand were not taxable.
Argument: Remittances to foreign corporations should be considered income of the agent and taxed accordingly. The remittances were contractual obligations and not taxable income.
Statute: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-Tax Act.
Rules: Any remittance made after realization of sales proceeds is considered income and taxable.
Precedent: Cases where agencies remitting funds had their profits taxed.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether remittances were profit repatriations or mere contractual obligations.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that S. K. F. was merely a conduit for transferring money, and the tax liability did not arise.

Case Name: Turner Morrison And Co., Ltd Vs. Hungerford Investment Trust Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether the claim for reimbursement of super tax was valid and enforceable under law.
Facts of the Case: Turner Morrison, acting as an agent, alleged it had paid super tax on behalf of Hungerford and was entitled to reimbursement. The defendant denied liability, arguing the payments were unauthorized or voluntary, and invoked estoppel, waiver, and limitation as defenses.
Ruling by Lower Court: Rejected the claim, stating that no conclusive proof of payment was presented, and the case was barred by limitation and estoppel.
Argument: Claimed entitlement to reimbursement for tax paid as an agent.
Statute: Principles of agency law and reimbursement claims under tax statutes.
Rules: A claim for reimbursement must be supported by legal authority and evidence of payment.
Precedent: Judicial rulings on voluntary payments and their enforceability.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether the payment was obligatory or voluntary, and if legal estoppel applied.
Ruling: Dismissed the appeal, stating that no valid claim.

Case Name: M/S. Corporate Ispat Alloys Limited Vs. M/S. Jayaswal Neco Industries Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the pending arbitration proceedings could act as a bar to the winding-up petition filed by the petitioner.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that arbitration should not prevent winding-up.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court delayed the case, reasoning that arbitration proceedings were relevant to the dispute.
Argument: The pending arbitration was not a legal barrier to the winding-up petition.  The court’s approach was justified as arbitration might resolve the dispute.
Rules: Company courts can proceed with winding-up even if arbitration is pending, unless specifically stayed.
Precedent: Prior cases where courts allowed winding-up despite arbitration disputes.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether winding-up proceedings should be postponed when arbitration is in progress.
Ruling: Held that the Company Court should not indefinitely delay the winding-up petition based on arbitration.

Case Name: National Organic Chemical Inds. Ltd Vs. Miheer H. Mafatlal
Issue Presented: Whether the approval of an Amalgamation Scheme could be challenged based on alleged violations of an injunction order.
Facts of the Case: The approval of the Scheme of Amalgamation became final with more than 75% shareholder approval.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Division Bench confirmed the merger scheme but upheld the ruling that share allotment was in contravention of the injunction.
Argument: The injunction order was not a decree, so it was not binding on the Company Court.
Statute: Section 155 of the Companies Act, 1956 (Rectification of Share Register).
Rules: Challenges to share allotment should be raised under Section 155 and not during merger approval proceedings.
Precedent: Prior rulings affirm that share ownership challenges must be filed separately under rectification laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether injunctions from lower courts can influence corporate merger proceedings.
Ruling: Held that the Company Court should not have examined share ownership.

Case Name: Anjuman Islamia and Others Vs. Munshi Tegh Ali and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the plaintiffs have ownership of Badi Takia and if it was dedicated as wakf property.
Facts of the Case: The plaintiffs asserted their absolute ownership over Badi Takia and sought damages for the placement of a tazia without their consent.
Ruling by Lower Court: Recognized the plaintiffs' ownership and dismissed the wakf claim.
Argument: Badi Takia was their inherited private property. No legal dedication as wakf existed.
Statute: Wakf Law & Ownership Rights in Islamic jurisprudence.
Rules: Courts must differentiate between private property and religious dedication.
Precedent: Prior cases have held that without a formal dedication, land remains private property.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether lack of formal dedication prevents a wakf from being recognized.
Ruling: Held that the plaintiffs were rightful owners, as no valid wakf dedication was established.

Case Name: Hindustan Petroleum Corpn. Ltd Vs. Ashok Ranghba Ambre
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court was correct in granting permanent employee status to the respondent.
Facts of the Case: The Labour Court ruled in favor of the respondent, and the High Court upheld this decision.
Ruling by Lower Court: Labour Court declared that the respondent should be considered a permanent employee from June 6, 1987.
Argument: The respondent did not undergo the proper hiring process.
Statute: Labour Laws governing casual and permanent employment in public-sector companies.
Rules: Government corporations must follow recruitment rules to grant permanent status.
Precedent: The courts have previously held that continuous service does not guarantee permanency.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether permanency can be granted despite lack of formal recruitment.
Ruling: Reversed the Court ruling, stating that casual employment does not grant permanency.

Case Name: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another Vs. State of Gujarat and Others
Petitioner: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether the Gujarat Industrial Development Act, 1962 was constitutionally valid and if the acquisition was for a public purpose.
Facts of the Case: The Gujarat Industrial Development Corporation, created under the 1962 Act, acquired multiple plots, including the appellant’s land.
Ruling by Lower Court: Rejected the constitutional challenge and affirmed that industrial development qualifies as a public purpose.
Argument: The acquisition violated property rights. The appellant’s land was critical for their textile business.
Statute: Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (governing public purpose acquisitions).
Rules: Industrial development is a recognized public purpose under Indian law.
Precedent: The Court has ruled that individual business interests do not outweigh public interest.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether land acquisition for industrial purposes justifies overriding individual property rights.
Ruling: Ruled in favor of the State of Gujarat.

Case Name: Pratima Chowdhury Vs. Kalpana Mukherjee
Issue Presented: Whether the transfer of Flat No. 5D to Pratima Chowdhury was legally valid and enforceable.
Facts of the Case: Indirani Bhattacharya resigned in favor of Pratima Chowdhury, executing a transfer agreement.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tribunal Decision upheld the transfer, stating that all procedural approvals were obtained.
Argument: The Deputy Registrar’s order confirmed her ownership.
Statute: Co-operative Societies Laws under West Bengal jurisdiction.
Rules: Transfers must be documented and approved.
Precedent: Courts have ruled that Registrar’s approval finalizes membership changes.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether legal ownership was rightfully transferred through proper documentation and approvals.
Ruling: Affirmed that the transfer was valid, dismissing any objections.

Case Name: P.P. Enterprises Etc. Vs. Union of India and Others Etc.
Issue Presented: Whether the storage limit regulations imposed by the government were arbitrary and violated Article 14.
Facts of the Case: The government restricted sugar storage limits based on population size and location.  - Dealers in Calcutta were given a special concession, while others had lower storage caps.
Ruling by Lower Court: The government's regulation was upheld, considering it a reasonable restriction under the Constitution.
Argument: The regulation imposed an excessive burden on non-Calcutta dealers.
Statute: Essential Commodities Act, 1955 (Regulation of Essential Goods).
Rules: The government has the right to regulate storage limits for essential commodities. Restrictions should not be arbitrary or excessive.
Precedent: Regulations must pass the reasonableness test to comply with constitutional principles.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether the classification in storage limits had a rational basis and was not arbitrary.
Ruling: The classification was deemed valid, as the government had a rational basis for differentiating storage limits.

Case Name: Ashok Kumar Barik Vs. State of Orissa
Issue Presented: Legitimacy of the conviction under Section 302 IPC and reliability of key witness testimonies.
Facts of the Case: A love affair between the petitioner and the deceased led to conflict due to caste differences.
Ruling by Lower Court: Conviction based on eyewitness testimonies (PWs 3 and 5) and medical corroboration
Argument: The conviction was based on weak evidence, and the High Court acknowledged inconsistencies.
Statute: Section 302 IPC (Punishment for Murder); Indian Penal Code.
Rules: Legal standards for homicide conviction include proving intent, causation, and reliability of witness testimony.
Precedent: Previous judgments emphasizing the need for reliable eyewitness accounts in murder cases.
Ratio of the Decision: The prosecution failed to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, leading to the High Court overturning the conviction.
Ruling: Court set aside the conviction, stating the case was not proven.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. The Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the Central Board of Revenue's order against Kartar Singh and whether procedural fairness was maintained.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was alleged to have provided shelter to Mukand Singh, who was involved in gold smuggling. The case relied on inferred knowledge rather than direct evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Board's decision was based on circumstantial evidence and inferences without direct proof.
Argument: The conclusions drawn by the Board were speculative, and the evidence presented did not establish guilt beyond doubt.
Rules: Convictions for smuggling require clear proof of intent and knowledge of illegal activity.
Precedent: Prior rulings requiring strict proof of intent in smuggling-related cases.
Ratio of the Decision: Procedural irregularities and lack of conclusive evidence led to the decision being overturned.
Ruling: The Board’s decision was ruled invalid due to lack of evidence.

Case Name: Surya Kant Roy Vs. Imamul Hai Khan
Issue Presented: Determining if the respondent's membership in the Mines Board of Health constituted an office of profit and if a police officer’s involvement affected the election’s fairness.
Facts of the Case: The Mines Board of Health was a statutory body with certain powers, but the respondent's role in it was debated as an office of profit.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court found that the respondent’s role in the Board did not meet the criteria for disqualification.
Argument: The respondent benefited from his membership in the Board, making him ineligible. The involvement of a police officer in the election further tainted the process.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1951; Indian Constitution (Article 102 and 191 on office of profit).
Rules: The definition of an office of profit depends on government control, financial benefits, and administrative influence.
Precedent: Previous rulings where government-appointed board members were not considered to hold an office of profit.
Ratio of the Decision: The Board was not under full government control, and the election process was not compromised.
Ruling: The High Court’s ruling was affirmed, and the election petition was rejected.

Case Name: Punjab Traders And Ors Vs. State Of Punjab And Ors
Issue Presented: The constitutionality of the Amendment Act, 1973, particularly whether it needed Presidential assent and if it unfairly impacted the appellants.
Facts of the Case: The Principal Act, governing molasses control, had been amended multiple times.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the amendment did not substantially change the Principal Act’s nature and was constitutional.
Argument: The amendment only clarified existing provisions and did not impose new legal burdens, making Article 304(b) inapplicable.
Statute: Article 304(b) (State taxation laws requiring Presidential assent), Article 14 (Right to Equality).
Rules: Amendments that do not impose new trade restrictions do not require Presidential assent.
Precedent: Cases where state laws affecting commerce were upheld without Presidential approval.
Ratio of the Decision: The amendment was procedural and did not alter the core framework of the Principal Act.
Ruling: The case was dismissed.

Case Name: Reena Suresh Alhat Vs. State Of Maharashtra And Anr
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court erred in dismissing the writ petition on grounds of constitutional bar and alternative remedy.
Facts of the Case: Reena Suresh Alhat’s nomination was rejected on 4.2.2017. Reshma Anil Bhosale was initially granted the BJP symbol, but the High Court stayed the order.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that electoral disputes should be resolved through the designated statutory mechanism rather than writ jurisdiction.
Argument: The High Court’s decision effectively removed the petitioners from the electoral process, violating democratic principles.
Statute: Election Commission rules on nomination and symbol allotment; Writ jurisdiction under the Constitution.
Rules: High Courts must avoid interfering in electoral processes unless there is a gross violation of fundamental rights.
Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on election symbol disputes and candidate nominations.
Ratio of the Decision: The issue was deemed significant enough to warrant Supreme Court intervention despite the existence of an alternative remedy.
Ruling: The Court held that the matter involved public importance and required judicial scrutiny.

Case Name: Karimbil Kunhikoman Vs. State Of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether the compensation structure under the Act creates unjustified discrimination among property owners.
Facts of the Case: The case involved the acquisition of land by the state under the power of eminent domain.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that the tiered system was legally valid as it followed a taxation-like structure.
Argument: Differential compensation is similar to progressive taxation, ensuring social justice.
Statute: Eminent domain principles; Property rights under Article 300A.
Rules: Landowners should receive equal compensation for equal deprivation.
Precedent: Judicial interpretations of Article 300A and right to property.
Ratio of the Decision: The compensation scheme violated the principle of equal treatment under eminent domain.
Ruling: The Court declared that all affected landowners should receive full compensation.

Case Name: Moideenkutty Haji Vs. Director General & Others
Issue Presented: Whether the additional roofing structure built by the petitioner is legally permissible under heritage and archaeological regulations.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner initially won the case before a Single Judge, but the Division Bench reversed the decision.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Division Bench overturned the ruling, stating the structure was not temporary and violated the law.
Argument: The roof was added to prevent dampness and structural degradation due to the building’s proximity to the sea.
Statute: Building regulations and heritage protection laws.
Rules: Temporary structures must be distinguished from permanent alterations under conservation laws.
Precedent: Prior rulings on heritage conservation and permissible alterations
Ratio of the Decision: The Court reviewed the structural integrity of the building and whether the aluminium roof could be classified as temporary.
Ruling: The Court considered the heritage implications and the need for legal compliance in protected structures.

Case Name: S. S. Shetty Vs. Bharat Nidhi, Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether reinstatement compensation should be calculated considering employment tenure, termination conditions, and employer obligations.
Facts of the Case: The employment agreement included pension and gratuity benefits, which were considered in determining compensation upon termination.
Ruling by Lower Court: The employer challenged the reinstatement award, arguing it should not be granted.
Argument: The financial compensation should not extend beyond termination, as future disputes cannot determine present obligations.
Rules: Reinstatement should consider tenure, termination conditions, and employer obligations under labor laws.
Precedent: Judicial rulings on employment termination benefits.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that reinstatement compensation must reflect actual service conditions and employment obligations.
Ruling: The judgment confirmed that the petitioner was entitled to reinstatement and compensation.

Case Name: Essco Fabs Pvt. Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether the Haryana government acted lawfully in denying the acquisition request for expansion of Essco’s Export Unit.
Facts of the Case: Essco, an export-oriented unit, sought land for expansion but was denied acquisition since the government deemed it not for public use. The land had been previously notified for acquisition but was later released.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the government was within its rights to reject Essco’s application.
Argument: The company contended that its activities benefited the economy, justifying land acquisition for expansion.
Rules: Public purpose under the Act is strictly interpreted for state-led development.
Precedent: Judicial interpretations restricting private acquisition requests
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment focused on whether economic benefits from exports justified compulsory acquisition.
Ruling: The court dismissed the appeal.

Case Name: Pankaj Kumar Vs. State of Jharkhand & Ors.
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner’s reservation benefits should be protected under the Bihar Reorganization Act, 2000 after absorption into Jharkhand’s services.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was a public employee in Bihar before Jharkhand’s creation on November 15, 2000. After being absorbed into Jharkhand’s services.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Jharkhand High Court ruled against the petitioner, stating that he should seek reservation benefits in Bihar.
Argument: The state contended that the petitioner’s status in Bihar does not automatically transfer to Jharkhand for reservation purposes.
Rules: Employees transferred due to state reorganization should not face disadvantages in service conditions.
Precedent: Cases where employment transfers did not affect reserved category benefits.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment examined whether state reorganization laws should protect employees from losing prior benefits.
Ruling: The judgment concluded that employees absorbed into Jharkhand’s services.

Case Name: K. Gopinathan Nair and Others Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether the assessees’ purchase of cashewnuts from CCI was part of an import transaction and thus immune from state taxation.
Facts of the Case: The appellants claimed that they placed orders through CCI for importing cashewnuts from African countries, and as these were imported for them.
Ruling by Lower Court: The tax authorities and the High Court ruled that the purchases did not constitute an import transaction and were liable for sales tax under state law.
Argument: The appellants argued that since CCI imported the cashewnuts exclusively for them, the sale should be classified as an import transaction.
Statute: Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963; Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 (Section 5(2)).
Rules: Sales that occur after goods have been imported into India do not qualify for exemption under Section 5(2).
Precedent: Previous cases where canalizing agencies facilitated imports but did not change the taxability of subsequent sales.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that once CCI took possession of the goods and sold them to the assessees.
Ruling: The appeals were dismissed.

Case Name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant is entitled to a refund of fees deposited before appeal.
Facts of the Case: The appellant had deposited a portion of the assessed market fees before filing appeals, which were ultimately dismissed.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that the deposited amount should not be refunded.
Argument: Harinagar Sugar Mills contended that the payments made should be returned since the Supreme Court had previously ruled on a similar issue.
Statute: Bihar Market Fee Act (Section 27-B); Articles 226 and 142 of the Constitution.
Rules: The ruling in Belsund Sugar Mills case applies prospectively, meaning past payments cannot be refunded, but pending liabilities cannot be recovered either.
Precedent: Supreme Court judgment in Belsund Sugar Mills case that determined how market fee liabilities should be handled.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling follows the principle that fees already paid remain with the government, while unpaid balances are not recoverable.
Ruling: All appeals were dismissed.

Case Name: P.C. Sethi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the seniority rules for temporary assistants violate the principle of continuous length of service.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, a temporary assistant, argued that the rules of seniority should follow continuous length of service.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court found that the application of different instructions was valid and did not violate constitutional principles.
Argument: The Union of India argued that seniority rules were based on valid administrative instructions and that continuous service.
Statute: Articles 14, 16, and 309 of the Constitution of India; Office Memoranda of 1949 and 1971.
Rules: The Office Memorandum of 1971 is no longer in force, and the government’s administrative instructions are valid.
Precedent: The case reinforces the principle that continuous service alone is not a basis for seniority unless conditions of absorption are met.
Ratio of the Decision: The Office Memorandum of 1971 does not automatically apply, and the government's seniority rules are valid under administrative law.
Ruling: The court upheld the validity of the seniority rules and dismissed the petition.

Case Name: Ruchi Majoo Vs. Sanjeev Majoo
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent (father) should be granted visitation rights and whether the appellant (mother) was wrong in preventing contact between the father and the child.
Facts of the Case: The respondent, who resides in a different country, claimed that he was being denied communication and access to his child.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court permitted some visitation rights but with restrictions.
Argument: The appellant claimed that the child had no interest in maintaining contact with the father, and forcing such interaction could harm the child’s emotional well-being.
Statute: Guardian and Wards Act, Family Law Principles.
Rules: The court ruled that virtual and in-person visitations must be permitted, and the appellant cannot interfere in any way.
Precedent: Reinforces the legal view that parental alienation is not in the best interests of the child and should be prevented by court orders.
Ratio of the Decision: The right of the father to communicate with his child cannot be obstructed by the mother.
Ruling: The court ruled in favor of the respondent.

Case Name: Charanjit Pal Jindal Vs. M/s. L.N. Metalics
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant’s failure to clear outstanding payments and the dishonoring of cheques constitutes an offense under the law.
Facts of the Case: The respondent supplied iron-related products to the appellant, who made partial payments but left a substantial amount unpaid.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Trial Court ruled against the appellant, affirming liability for the dishonored cheques.
Argument: The respondent emphasized that the appellant made repeated false promises and failed to honor financial commitments, justifying legal proceedings.
Statute: Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
Rules: Issuing cheques without sufficient funds is punishable, and the appellant was found guilty.
Precedent: Upholds the legal principle that failure to clear outstanding dues via dishonored cheques can lead to criminal conviction.
Ratio of the Decision: The appellant’s conduct demonstrated negligence in honoring financial commitments, warranting conviction.
Ruling: The conviction was confirmed, and the appeal was rejected.

Case Name: State of Haryana Vs. Northern Indian Glass Industries Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court was correct in setting aside the State's resumption notice and directing reconsideration with adherence to natural justice.
Facts of the Case: The respondent sought land for industrial purposes, leading to the State's acquisition and transfer under the Land Acquisition Act. Disputes arose over compensation, culminating in a High Court ruling increasing the amount.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Collector confirmed the compensation award, maintaining the original acquisition terms.
Argument: The State maintained that resumption was necessary as the land did not fulfill its original industrial purpose, thus warranting reclaiming.
Rules: The requirement to follow natural justice was a key factor in setting aside the resumption notice.
Precedent: Upholds the principle of natural justice in State-led land resumptions.
Ratio of the Decision: The absence of fair hearing for the respondent and subsequent purchasers warranted the High Court's intervention.
Ruling: The High Court's ruling was affirmed, requiring due process before any resumption.

Case Name: Ms. Sarita Singh Vs. M/s Shree Infosoft Private Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the employment contract terms regarding deputation applied to the petitioner and whether the respondent discharged the burden of proof.
Facts of the Case: The employment agreement allowed the respondent to post the petitioner at any location, including overseas. It also imposed a service obligation post-deputation.
Ruling by Lower Court: Not specified
Argument: The petitioner maintained that her travel was for a business meeting, not deputation, and that the respondent had no valid grounds to enforce a service obligation.
Rules: The court examined whether the respondent followed proper procedures to classify the petitioner's travel as deputation.
Precedent: The State of Punjab v. Inder Singh case was cited to define deputation and the requirement of consent.
Ratio of the Decision: The absence of documented proof meant the respondent could not enforce the deputation clause against the petitioner.
Ruling: The respondent's claim was dismissed due to lack of evidence.

Case Name: Parmanand Patel (D) Th. Lrs. Vs. Sudha A. Chowgule
Petitioner: Legal representatives of late Parmanand Patel
Issue Presented: Whether the second set of documents, particularly the undated will and letters, were legally enforceable or executed under coercion.
Facts of the Case: Late Parmanand Patel allegedly prepared documents to divide his property equally among his daughters.
Ruling by Lower Court: The trial court upheld the second set of documents as binding and enforceable.
Argument: The petitioners claimed that the documents were altered under coercion and that Sudha's actions were detrimental to Parmanand Patel’s true intentions.
Statute: Indian Contract Act, Succession Law, Wills and Testamentary Documents.
Rules: The enforceability of testamentary documents in cases involving allegations of coercion was a key consideration.
Precedent: Upholds the requirement that testamentary documents must reflect the true intent of the deceased.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized the importance of ensuring legal safeguards against undue influence but sided with Sudha.
Ruling: The High Court’s ruling was upheld, allowing Sudha to retain her legal rights over the estate.

Case Name: Patel Ahmed Mohammad Vs. Balwant Singh Rajput
Issue Presented: Whether Patel Ahmed Mohammad’s election was influenced by bribery, undue influence, and illegal vote counting as per Section 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Facts of the Case: The appellant (Patel Ahmed Mohammad) was elected to the Rajya Sabha on 8th August 2017. The petitioner (Balwant Singh Rajput) alleged corrupt practices.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the appellant’s preliminary objections and allowed the election petition to proceed.
Argument: Claimed that two valid votes were improperly rejected and two invalid votes were accepted, materially affecting the election. Also alleged corrupt practices by the appellant.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1951; Election Laws.
Rules: The court focused on whether procedural non-compliance warranted dismissal and if allegations of electoral malpractice required further inquiry.
Precedent: Establishes that allegations of electoral malpractice must be examined through trial rather than being summarily dismissed.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment affirmed that procedural objections could not override substantive claims of election misconduct.
Ruling: The court upheld the maintainability of the petition, leading to further judicial proceedings on the allegations.

Case Name: Podar Mills Limited Vs. State Bank of India
Issue Presented: Whether the appointment of a receiver for the mortgaged property was appropriate given the financial situation of Podar Mills Limited.
Facts of the Case: The State Bank of India sought recovery of outstanding dues from Podar Mills Limited. Due to financial mismanagement, the company’s assets were vested with the Custodian under the Taking Over of Management Act.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Single Judge ruled in favor of appointing a receiver to safeguard the mortgaged property.
Argument: Asserted that the appointment of a receiver was unnecessary and that the company was unable to respond effectively due to lack of access to financial records.
Statute: Transfer of Property Act, 1882; Indian Contract Act.
Rules: Examined legal provisions related to mortgage recovery and judicial discretion in appointing receivers.
Precedent: Reinforced the principle that courts can appoint receivers in financial disputes when just and convenient.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that protecting public funds and ensuring loan recovery warranted the receiver’s appointment.
Ruling: The court upheld the lower court’s decision to appoint a receiver.

Case Name: The Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. Shri D. K. Worlikar
Issue Presented: Whether the scope of the government notification includes all aspects of the sugar industry or only sugar manufacturing and its by-products.
Facts of the Case: Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd challenged the Labour Appellate Tribunal’s decision, arguing that the notification did not encompass the entire sugar industry but was restricted to the manufacture of sugar and its by-products.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Labour Court held that the notification had a limited scope and did not cover the broader sugar industry.
Argument: Asserted that the intent of the notification was to regulate all aspects of the sugar industry, not just manufacturing.
Rules: Examined whether the Tribunal’s interpretation was justified based on the notification’s wording.
Precedent: Establishes that government notifications must be read within their defined scope rather than being broadly extended.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling clarified that the notification’s scope was limited and could not be extended beyond its explicit wording.
Ruling: The Supreme Court overturned the Tribunal’s decision, reinstating the Labour Court’s interpretation.

Case Name: RANI Vs. NATIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY LTD
Petitioner: Rani (Claimants in Civil Appeal No.9078 of 2017) and Anand
Respondent: National Insurance Company Ltd & Offending vehicle owner
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court was correct in restricting the liability of the Insurance Company and whether compensation should be increased.
Facts of the Case: The claimants (legal heirs of Satish and injured pillion rider Anand) sought enhanced compensation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal determined the compensation amounts but did not address whether the Insurance Company should pay first and recover from the owner.
Argument: The appellants contended that the Insurance Company should be made to pay first and recover later, as it would be unfair to leave the claimants without compensation.
Rules: The Court examined whether the insurance policy covered the case despite the lack of a valid permit and if the "pay and recover" principle applied.
Precedent: The case clarified that compensation enhancement is possible even if liability is contested.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment weighed the rights of accident victims against statutory insurance exclusions.
Ruling: The Court acknowledged the claimants’ entitlement to compensation but maintained legal restrictions on the Insurance Company.

Case Name: B. M. Ramaswamy Vs. B. M. Krishnamurthy And Others
Issue Presented: Whether failure to follow statutory procedures affected the validity of the petitioner's inclusion in the electoral roll.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s name was not included in the electoral roll in compliance with the statutory procedure.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal upheld the decision that the electoral officer did not follow due process.
Argument: The petitioner contended that procedural lapses should not impact substantive electoral rights.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1950; Representation of the People Rules, 1956.
Rules: The Court examined the balance between strict procedural adherence and substantive electoral rights.
Precedent: It clarified that adherence to statutory requirements in electoral procedures is fundamental.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment weighed procedural compliance against electoral fairness.
Ruling: The Court upheld the importance of following electoral procedures and ruled against the petitioner.

Case Name: Bhabhi Vs. Sheo Govind & Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court erred in granting a sample inspection order without verifying the substantive evidence.
Facts of the Case: The respondent challenged the election outcome and sought sample inspection, claiming irregularities. However, the request lacked material particulars, including the serial numbers of disputed ballots and details of the alleged irregularities.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court granted the respondent's request without properly assessing evidence.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the respondent did not furnish material details about alleged irregularities and failed to follow proper election procedures.
Statute: Conduct of Election Rules, 1961; Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Rules: The Court reaffirmed that procedural fairness is essential in electoral matters and that requests for inspection require specific allegations and material proof.
Precedent: It established that judicial intervention in election matters must be based on well-founded allegations, not mere claims.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reinforced that courts should not disrupt electoral processes without substantial proof of irregularities.
Ruling: The ruling invalidated the High Court’s order and upheld the importance of procedural compliance.

Case Name: Kathiawar Industries Limited Vs. Jaffrabad Municipality
Issue Presented: Whether the process of crushing salt within octroi limits constitutes "use" or "consumption" under tax law.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner transported raw salt into the octroi area for processing and subsequent export. The municipality claimed that this processing amounted to local "use," making it taxable.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that transforming raw salt into crushed salt amounted to "use," justifying the octroi levy.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the purpose of bringing the salt into the factory was not for consumption but for processing and subsequent export.
Statute: Section 3 of the Octroi Act; Burmah Shell Oil Storage & Distributing Co. India Ltd. v. The Belgaum Borough Municipality.
Rules: The ruling emphasized that processing goods in a local area satisfies octroi taxability criteria.
Precedent: It clarified the scope of taxation for goods undergoing local processing before export.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored that "use" is not limited to consumption but includes activities enhancing the value of goods.
Ruling: The appeal was dismissed, and the octroi tax was deemed valid.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras Vs. M/S. Madurai Mills Co. Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the receipt of assets from liquidated companies results in capital gains taxable.
Facts of the Case: Madurai Mills Co. Ltd. received assets worth Rs. 4,57,858, Rs. 1,41,739, and Rs. 1,83,175 upon the liquidation of three companies in which it held shares.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal found that the transaction did not constitute a taxable capital gain.
Argument: The Commissioner argued that any gains realized from liquidation should be taxed as capital gains.
Statute: Section 12B(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
Rules: The judgment emphasized that liquidation distributions are not taxable events under capital gains provisions.
Precedent: It clarified the tax treatment of assets received from liquidated entities.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling underscored that the mere receipt of liquidation proceeds is not a taxable event.
Ruling: The appeal was dismissed, confirming that no capital gains tax was applicable.

Case Name: Union of India and Anr Vs. Pfizer Limited and Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the impugned Regulation exceeded the scope of Section 26A.
Facts of the Case: The government sought to regulate certain pharmaceutical products, leading to a dispute over the interpretation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court found that the regulatory action lacked sufficient justification and struck down the restrictions.
Argument: The government argued that its actions were necessary for consumer safety and fell within the intended scope of Section 26A.
Statute: Section 26A of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940.
Rules: The ruling emphasized that legislative provisions should be interpreted within their explicit textual boundaries.
Precedent: The decision reinforced the principle that judicial intervention is necessary when legislative overreach is evident.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored that regulatory decisions must be proportionate and legally justified.
Ruling: The Court invalidated the impugned regulation, declaring it ultra vires.

Case Name: Indian Young Lawyers Association Vs. State of Kerala (Sabarimala Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the ban on women of menstruating age entering Sabarimala Temple is unconstitutional.
Facts of the Case: The case involved a challenge to the temple’s practice of restricting women’s entry based on religious customs.
Ruling by Lower Court: Kerala High Court ruled in favor of the temple’s authority to impose entry restrictions.
Argument: The argument was that religious practices cannot supersede fundamental rights of gender equality and non-discrimination.
Rules: The Constitution ensures the right to equality, and customs restricting fundamental rights must be scrutinized.
Precedent: Cases involving conflicts between religious customs and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Customs that violate fundamental rights must be reconsidered in light of constitutional principles.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of gender equality, allowing women to enter Sabarimala Temple.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Praful Desai
Issue Presented: Whether testimony recorded through video conferencing is admissible in court.
Facts of the Case: The prosecution wanted to record testimony via video conferencing due to the witness’s inability to appear in person.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court rejected video conferencing, stating it did not meet traditional evidentiary requirements.
Argument: The prosecution contended that video conferencing ensures justice while preventing undue delays.
Rules: Testimony does not have to be physically in person if reliable technology ensures credibility.
Precedent: Cases supporting the integration of modern technology in legal proceedings.
Ratio of the Decision: Courts should adapt to technological advancements to facilitate justice and efficiency.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the use of video conferencing, stating it meets legal standards for testimony.

Case Name: Shabnam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether an inordinate delay in processing mercy petitions constitutes cruel and inhumane treatment.
Facts of the Case: The case involved the challenge to an excessive delay in the rejection of a mercy petition, which the petitioner claimed was a violation of fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against the petitioner, maintaining that the death sentence was valid despite the delay.
Argument: The argument centered on the psychological suffering caused by prolonged uncertainty, which the petitioner claimed infringed on her fundamental rights.
Rules: Delays in execution decisions must be reasonable and justified to avoid violating constitutional rights.
Precedent: Cases establishing that prolonged delays in deciding mercy petitions may violate human rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Prolonged delay in processing a mercy plea violates the right to life and dignity.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the extended delay justified commuting the sentence to life imprisonment.

Case Name: Ritesh Sinha Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether obtaining a voice sample from an accused is a violation.
Facts of the Case: The prosecution sought a voice sample for forensic examination, but the petitioner argued that it amounted to self-incrimination.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held that voice samples do not amount to self-incriminating evidence under Article 20(3).
Argument: The petitioner argued that voice samples contain personal information and compelling them violates the right against self-incrimination.
Rules: The right against self-incrimination extends to compelled testimony, but not to physical evidence like fingerprints or voice samples.
Precedent: Cases distinguishing between physical evidence and testimonial compulsion under Article 20(3).
Ratio of the Decision: Since a voice sample is only a physical characteristic, it does not fall under the prohibition of self-incrimination.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that a voice sample can be taken for investigative purposes without violating fundamental rights.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax II Vs. M/s. Modipon Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether the excise duty deposit made in the PLA can be considered as duty payment for accounting and refund purposes.
Facts of the Case: Modipon Ltd. maintained a practice of depositing excise duty in a PLA, from which deductions were made upon clearance of goods.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower courts upheld Modipon Ltd.'s position, accepting its accounting treatment and rejecting the Revenue’s claim.
Argument: The Revenue maintained that PLA deposits were not actual duty payments but provisional estimates adjusted at clearance.
Statute: Section 3 of the Central Excise Act, 1944; Rule 173G of the Central Excise Rules, 1944.
Rules: The judgment emphasized the statutory interpretation of duty deposits and refund provisions.
Precedent: The decision affirmed that established accounting practices should not be altered arbitrarily by the Revenue.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored that PLA deposits are tax obligations and that the Revenue cannot reject them arbitrarily.
Ruling: The Court upheld the taxpayer’s claim, rejecting the Revenue’s argument that PLA deposits were not tax payments.

Case Name: Gopal Singh And Others Vs. Ujagar Singh And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the property was ancestral and if the daughter, Mst. Biro, had only a life estate, making her gift to her sons invalid.
Facts of the Case: The plaintiffs contended that the gift by Mst. Biro was invalid as the property was ancestral. The defendants argued that, under customary law, collaterals beyond the fifth degree were not heirs in the presence of a daughter and her line.
Ruling by Lower Court: The trial court ruled that the daughter's gift to her sons accelerated the estate, and the plaintiffs had no standing to challenge it.
Argument: The plaintiffs claimed that customary law allowed them, as presumptive reversioners, to inherit the property after the daughter's death.
Statute: Customary law principles related to property inheritance and the validity of gifts made by daughters.
Rules: The decision was based onthe established legal principles governing ancestral property and the rights of daughters in alienating property.
Precedent: The ruling affirmed that reversionary rights do not exist when the property is non-ancestral and that gifts by daughters can be valid.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment clarified that under customary law, daughters could validly alienate property when collaterals were beyond the fifth degree.
Ruling: The High Court ruled in favor of the defendants.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N. Sami Iyer
Issue Presented: Whether the assessee was liable for sales tax on the same transaction under the newly extended Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act despite prior taxation.
Facts of the Case: The case arose due to the transition from the Madras Act to the Travancore-Cochin Act, with the assessee contesting double taxation on the same goods.
Ruling by Lower Court: The authorities ruled in favor of the state, maintaining that taxation under the new Act was justified.
Argument: The appellant contended that the Madras Act's provisions no longer applied, and the turnover was subject to taxation under the new law.
Statute: Section 3(5) of the Madras General Sales Tax Act, which prevents double taxation in a single transaction.
Rules: Interpretation of tax laws to determine whether turnover assessed under a previous Act could be reassessed under a newly extended Act.
Precedent: The case affirmed that transitional changes in tax laws should not result in unfair double taxation on the same transaction.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision was based on statutory interpretation, emphasizing that taxation laws must be applied consistently without imposing undue burdens on dealers.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision that the turnover was not liable to additional taxation.

Case Name: Punj Lloyd Limited Vs. Corporate Risks India Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant was wrongfully denied relief under consumer protection law due to the Commission’s finding that the matter involved disputed facts.
Facts of the Case: Corporate Risks India Pvt. Ltd. identified Oriental Insurance Company Ltd. as the insurer and conveyed the premium cost to Punj Lloyd. Relying on this, Punj Lloyd transferred the full amount to the broker.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Commission ruled that the appellant had raised complex contentions unsuitable for adjudication under consumer law and, therefore, dismissed the complaint summarily.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the dispute involved misrepresentation and deficiency in service rather than complex contractual questions, making it fit for adjudication under consumer law.
Rules: The ruling considered principles governing summary dismissal and the scope of consumer protection law in contractual disputes.
Precedent: The ruling reaffirmed that complex contractual matters are generally unsuitable for summary disposal under consumer forums but must be assessed on a case-by-case basis.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment clarified that consumer forums have limited jurisdiction over contractual disputes but must not dismiss valid consumer grievances outright.
Ruling: The High Court ruled that the Commission had erred in dismissing the case without proper examination and ordered a rehearing.

Case Name: State of Assam Vs. The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Respondent: The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Issue Presented: Whether the notification of December 4, 1959, bringing a portion of Naharkatia Tea Estate under municipal taxation, was ultra vires.
Facts of the Case: The respondent, Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited, claimed that the estate was self-sufficient and did not require municipal services. The company argued that the notification was issued solely to increase municipal revenue and was beyond the powers conferred by the Assam Municipal Act.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that the notification was beyond the powers granted by the Assam Municipal Act and restrained the Town Committee from enforcing municipal taxes on the estate.
Argument: The government argued that the inclusion of the tea estate in the municipal area was a valid administrative decision and that taxation was necessary for equitable municipal development.
Rules: The case examined the principles of municipal taxation and whether a self-sufficient estate.
Precedent: The ruling clarified the limitations of municipal powers in designating areas for taxation.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reaffirmed that municipal governance must be exercised within statutory limits and not used as a tool for unjust taxation.
Ruling: The appeal was dismissed, and the High Court’s ruling invalidating the notification was maintained.

Case Name: Union Public Service Commission Vs. Shristi Singh
Issue Presented: Whether the rejection of Shristi Singh’s candidature for the post of Drug Inspector was legally valid.
Facts of the Case: The advertisement for Drug Inspector mandated 18 months of experience in testing drugs under Schedule ‘C’ and ‘C-1’ of the Drugs and Cosmetics Rules.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal allowed Singh’s participation in the interview, subject to her performance exceeding the last selected candidate in her category.
Argument: UPSC contended that adherence to the specified experience criteria was mandatory and that Singh failed to meet the requirement.
Rules: The case examined the strictness of eligibility criteria and whether UPSC’s interpretation was reasonable.
Precedent: The ruling clarified the role of tribunals in reviewing administrative decisions on eligibility.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision affirmed that tribunals have the authority to review recruitment eligibility decisions if they appear arbitrary.
Ruling: The appeal was dismissed, and the Tribunal’s order allowing Singh’s interview was upheld.

Case Name: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Anr Vs. Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Anr
Petitioner: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Another
Respondent: Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether the demand for arrears by NESCO was legally justified when the property was sold on an "as-is-where-is" basis.
Facts of the Case: NESCO refused to provide power unless the outstanding dues of the previous owner were cleared. The respondent approached the High Court, arguing that they were not liable for past dues.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Judge ruled in favor of NESCO, affirming that outstanding dues had to be cleared before power restoration.
Argument: NESCO maintained that electricity dues were a charge on the property and were recoverable from the new owner before providing any fresh supply.
Statute: Electricity Act, 2003; Orissa Electricity Regulatory Commission (OERC) Regulations.
Rules: The decision analyzed whether electricity dues are a charge on the property that automatically transfers to new owners in liquidation sales.
Precedent: The ruling established that unless expressly stated in law, a new purchaser cannot be burdened with past dues of the previous owner.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment reaffirmed that contractual obligations must be respected, and the mere ownership transfer does not create financial liabilities unless specified.
Ruling: The appeal was allowed, and the Supreme Court held that NESCO could not demand arrears.

Case Name: Subodh Gopal Bose Vs. Ajit Kumar Haldar And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the plaintiff could claim the estate free from encumbranceS.
Facts of the Case: The plaintiff acquired the estate in an auction sale due to arrears. The main contention was whether the tenure held by the defendants could be annulled under Section 37 of the Amending Act.
Ruling by Lower Court: The trial court determined that the plaintiff, as the estate purchaser, had the right to annul the tenure under the Amending Act.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the estate was acquired free from encumbrances, and the defendants’ tenure did not qualify for exemption.
Statute: Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885; Estate Sale Regulations, Section 37.
Rules: The court assessed whether the tenure of the defendants was legally protected under the Amending Act.
Precedent: The case clarified that an appeal is a continuation of the original suit, making the Amending Act applicable even if it was enacted after the suit was filed.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored that encumbrances on an estate sold for arrears do not transfer unless they fall within statutory exceptions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the lower court's ruling, affirming that the estate was acquired free from encumbrances.

Case Name: Beni Madhab Shaw Alias Benia Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner's detention complied with the legal provisions of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was detained for alleged involvement in theft from railway wagons and attacks on railway security, affecting the supply of essential commodities.
Ruling by Lower Court: Not explicitly stated.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that that the detention was unlawful because the State cited the wrong legal provision, indicating procedural lapses.
Rules: The court examined the validity of the detention order based on statutory interpretations of the Essential Commodities Act.
Precedent: The decision highlighted that authorities must accurately cite legal provisions when issuing detention orders.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling reaffirmed the importance of due process in preventive detention cases.
Ruling: The Supreme Court set aside the detention order.

Case Name: Raghu Raj Singh Rousha Vs. M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Respondent: M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to decide the matter in the absence of the accused under Sections 397 and 401 of the CrPC.
Facts of the Case: The respondent company filed a complaint before the Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, alleging fraud and forgery.
Ruling by Lower Court: The magistrate rejected the request for an investigation, citing the contractual nature of the dispute.
Argument: The petitioner contended that issuing an order under Sections without hearing the accused was procedurally improper.
Statute: Sections 397, 401, and 156(3) of the CrPC; IPC provisions on forgery and fraud.
Rules: The court analyzed whether procedural fairness required the accused’s presence before issuing an order.
Precedent: The decision clarified the scope of High Court powers under Sections 397 and 401 CrPC.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized that orders in revision should not be made without giving the accused an opportunity to present their case.
Ruling: The Court set aside the High Court’s decision, holding that the accused must be given an opportunity to be heard.
